p.strong: The Effects of the Mentoring System on the Achievement of student in Project Management Course

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Education al Research Methods
Author's preference: Oral

p.em: 1Qassim University, Buraidah City, Saudi Arabia, 2AUT, Auckland, New Zealand, 3FEATI University, Manila, The Philippines

body.p: The quasi-experimental design involving two groups of 105 engineering student in Project Management course of comparable mental ability was used in this study. One group was exposed to mentoring system while the other was not. Test result in practical problem solving case studies and achievement test of two equivalent classes in Project Management were compared for 3 grading periods. The experimental class (n=50) was taught using the mentoring system strategy while control (n=55) was taught the traditional method, which is predominantly teacher-oriented. It was found that the mentoring system strategy improved the student practical problem solving case studies ability only slightly increased achievement test scores, it made the engineering student more responsible to each other. This was visible when the mentoring tutor prepared his own exercises for the tutorial sessions; the engineering student who were taught in mentoring system strategy gave detailed SWOT analysis in case study of project management course.

p.strong: Enhancing the Civil Engineering Project Courses in the BSCE Curriculum of FEATI University

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Curriculum Development
Author's preference: Oral

Several momentous and significant events happening all over the world make the paradigm change in the method of teaching in the Philippines. The first is globalization. High technology has shrunk the world so drastically that professionals have to compete with others in their field internationally. This simply means that if Civil Engineering student will not learn to research and invent new technology, the newly CE graduates will hardly stand a chance in the global competition. The design of Civil Engineering Project courses that will use their technical engineering knowledge in construction and management engineering, highway and transportation engineering, structural engineering and water resources engineering will enhance or prove concepts will go a long way in developing future civil engineers who are aware, concerned and innovative in dealing with work situations. This research paper presents innovations made in the project courses of the Civil Engineering program in line with the objective of enhancing the learning process. Civil engineers become more effective if he has acquired the proper education and training.

p.strong: Adapting Team-Based Learning to FacilitateDevelopment of Competencies and Skills Needed for Global Engineering Competitiveness

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: The Global Engineer
Author's preference: Oral

p.em: University of Missouri, Columbia, Missouri, USA

body.p: Industry and accrediting agencies are telling us that when many of today's engineering student enter the work force, they will find themselves on multi-disciplinary and diverse international teams solving global-scale problems. The skills needed to be successful in that setting include superior technical competence and excellent professional skills. Research shows that student-centred active learning tends to produce better conceptual understanding than does traditional passive lecture-based learning, and that when active learning is conducted in an extensively group-based environment, student can also develop various professional skills, such as self-directed independent learning, problem-solving,and interpersonal team skills. Team-Based Learning (TBL) is a form of group-based student-centred learning in which student independently study new conceptual material before it is treated in the classroom, and then subsequently spend considerable classroom time working in teams on increasingly challenging applications of that new material. A recent initiative to use TBL as the principal teaching and learning strategy in the second-year electric circuit theory sequence has led to several beneficial revisions to the basic TBL process. This paper describes those changes, with emphasis on professional skills development. Continuous assessment instruments used to assess learning of professional skills are described, and evaluative measures that illustrate the effectiveness of the revised strategy are also described.

p.strong: Curriculum Development of Hardware Interfacing System for Visual C++ in Computer Engineering Course

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Curriculum Development
Author's preference: Oral

Doyce Tesoro-Martinez1, Harold Taylor1, Tomas Ganiron Jr1 1University of Auckland, Auckland, New Zealand, 2Victoria University of Wellington, Wellington, New Zealand, 3Auckland University of Technology, Auckland, New Zealand

The College of Computer Engineering rides stop the crest of the new millennium. This is the reason of its curriculum revision in hardware interfacing system course. Furthermore, the revision was made for the course to be internationally and globally competitive, relevant to local conditions and with strong industry linkage components. Although this course was comparable to that of most other university, it had neither the rigour nor the practical experience needed to prepare undergraduates for the workplace or meaningful graduate study. The student and faculty responses have been very favourable. They are excited by the new course and the closed laboratory component. The hardware interfacing system course has lecture slides, laboratory activities, homework assignments, etc. available on the web for public viewing

p.strong: Virtuality, interdisciplinarity, collaborativeness: Assessing student outcomes for I-EDU Innovative Engineering Instructional Project

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Curriculum Development
Author's preference: Oral

The rapid development of information technology propels knowledge explosion and the progress of human civilization. Meanwhile, the ubiquitous computers, internet, and mobile devices have changed the means people absorb and create knowledge. Recently, cultivating creativity as an ability and building creative talent has become the focus for the higher education researchers in the engineering and design realm.

Consequently, the current research centers on establishing and evaluating an innovative engineering instructional model (I-EDU Project) , which aims to ameliorate student' passive and conventional individual-focused learning model, as well as to enhance their essential competencies such as exploration, reflection, teamwork and creativity. I-EDU project consists of six projects, with five innovative course projects and an assessment study, implemented in a comprehensive university in Taiwan. I-EDU proposes three major instructional elements, that is, virtuality, interdisciplinary and collaborativeness, implemented in the five innovative engineering courses to increase student' core competencies, including: observation, reflection, imagination, teamwork and interdisciplinary communication.

The current research is I-EDU's assessment project, taking the role of evaluating and examining student outcomes of the five innovative engineering courses. Specifically, this research examines how the design of these courses characteristic of virtuality, interdisciplinarity and collaborativeness made impact on student' imagination and creativity. Through literature review, expert consultation, establishment of questionnaires, and instructional experiment, this research assessed student outcomes in order to provide timely feedback for the project courses. Ultimately, the result of this current research are beneficial to setting indicative reference for cultivating innovative engineering talent and increase their competitiveness.

p.strong: Sustainable development in Engineering university, how accreditation agencies can help them in this demarch? The case of French HEIandits application in Polytech Orl?s

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Sustainability in EE
Author's preference: Oral
Anne-Marie JOLLY1 ,2, Christophe LEGER1, Jean-Yves CADOREL1 1Universit?'Orl?s, Orl?s, France, 2Commission des Titres d' Ing?eurs, France, France

Though much work has been done since 2002 at the European level to include Sustainable Development in Engineering Education, it appears that a rather important part of Engineering HEIs has not included SD in its global strategy. After an incitation period, it is perhaps necessary to go to mandatory actions. Quality agencies can be the frame for such actions. As an example, in February 2014, the French Agency "Commission des Titres d' Ing?eurs" made mandatory for all engineering education institutions to define a strategy concerning sustainable development and to apply it. It became immediately a criteria for evaluation. As in the ISO norms concerning SD, many fields are concerned:the strategy and policy of the institution, the social management and link with the territory, the environmental management, research, education, documentation, links with enterprises, the quality and progress strategy of the institution. Each institution can implement Green Plan according to its specificities. As an example of application, the way Polytech Orl?s has implemented these recommendations to its specificity, implying student, teachers and stake holders is presented together with others examples of "Green Plan" in Engineering institutions.

p.strong: Perspectives and Expectations of Engineering Curriculum and Graduates' Employability by StakeholdersBased on the Survey to 6 university and 20 Enterprises in China

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Curriculum Development
Author's preference: Oral
Jun Cui, Jian Chen Southeast University, Nanjing, Jiangsu, China

The purpose of this paper is to illustrate the perspectives and expectations from engineering education stakeholders including graduates and employers for engineering curriculum and graduates' employability.

This study contains three research questions. First, how satisfied are senior student with the curricula enhancing employability? Second, how satisfied and expected are employers with the employability of engineering graduates? Third, what're the differences among graduates' satisfaction, employers' satisfaction and employers' expectation?

Questionnaire investigations and interviews are combined to collect data and both stratified sampling and purposive sampling method are adopted. Student samples are 600 senior student from 6 university and employer samples are 300 employers from 20 enterprises. The location regions, engineering fields and types of the enterprises are evenly distributed.

The result of this study are as followings. First, student' satisfaction degree of the curricula enhancing employability is not high, which is significantly different in university and fields. Second, employers' satisfaction degree of engineering graduates' employability is not high either and there is a gap between employers' satisfaction and their expectation. Third, student' satisfaction degree of the curricula enhancing employability and employers' satisfaction degree of graduates' employability are significantly lower than employers' expectation value.

The author conclude that engineering curriculum reform must take the stakeholders' demand into account integrate employability into curricula and focus on developing student technical hard skills as well as non-technical soft skills. This study provides empirical evidence from perspectives of stakeholders for cultivating engineers of high quality and deepening the reform of engineering curriculum.

p.strong: activities Led Learning and Developing Professional Judgement Capacity in Undergraduate Learners.

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Active Learning
Author's preference: Oral
Hal Igarashi, John Davies, Sarah Wilson-Medhurst Coventry University, Coventry, UK
activities Led Learning and Developing Professional Judgement Capacity in Undergraduate Learners.
Hal Igarashi, John Davies, Sarah Wilson-Medhurst. Coventry University.

Research has indicated that the domain specific knowledge of new professional entrants and professional experts is largely similar, and that professional performance of experts is predicated in flexible behaviours and the way that professionals organise knowledge and exercise judgement. Traditionally new professional entrants acquired these skills in a community of practice after leaving university. This paper proposes that activities Led Learning (ALL) with strong relevance to the dynamics and structuralism of real world problems, may provide a learning environment in which the learner can organise and analyse information and exercise the making of judgements to synthesize new knowledge and develop modified or new habits of action. An opportunistic sample of undergraduate and apprentice engineering learners participating in a range of self directed engineering projects were observed and their activities and learning environment recorded. The projects ran for durations of between 10 to 32 weeks. A range of learners were selected at random and interviewed. The data collected was encoded to determine the kinds of judgements the learners made. Preliminary findings within the experiences observed suggest that ALL experiences can be constructed to provide opportunities that compel learners to exercise making complex judgements across a diverse range of technical and holistic contexts similar to those of engineering professionals.

p.strong: Working with student' diversity toward high-level skills by means of PBL

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Issues of Gender and Diversity
Author's preference: Oral
Nestor Arana-Arexolaleiba, I?? Velez-de-Mendizabal, E?? Muxika-Olasagasti, Txema Perez-Lazare Mondragon University, Arrasate-Mondrag??Spain

Nowadays, university offer its services to a greater diversity of student. During 20th century, university have passed from an elite university, to a mass university with a larger proportion of cohorts. In the mass university there is a greater variety of student with different learning approach. Nevertheless, society is asking for student with high-level skills. Those skills go beyond understanding basic knowledge and acquiring basic skills. It is well known that Problem and Project Based Learning (PBL) methodology is adapted to acquire such skills. In this work, we wish to understand the impact of the student's learning approach and their supervisions sessions on high level skills in a PBL context. To carry out this study, Design Based Research method has been used. Several information sources have been used: At the beginning and at the end of the process student' learning approach has been measured. In addition, two different non structured focus group discussions have been organized: the first one with supervisors and the second one with student. In this paper, preliminary result will be shown and discussed.

p.strong: Competence-oriented assignments in the mathematical education of mechanical engineers

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Maths in EE
Author's preference: Oral

In the new edition of the curriculum document issued by SEFI's Mathematics Working Group in 2013 (see http://sefi.htw-aalen.de) the concept of mathematical competence as developed in the Danish KOM project serves to capture higher-level learning goals in the mathematical education of engineers. Mathematical competence is defined as "the ability to understand, judge, do and use mathematics in a variety of intra- and extra-mathematical contexts and situations where mathematics plays or could play a role". Assignments given to student are the most important vehicle for achieving educational goals in mathematics (ranging from small, well-defined computational tasks to open and challenging projects). Therefore, for really putting the competence concept into practice, we need assignments that are suitable for acquiring the competence goals (for example those stated by the author in a mathematics curriculum for a practice-oriented study course in mechanical engineering, cf. the website stated above).

In this contribution, we present examples for such assignments in the area of mechanical engineering and we state some guidelines on how to identify such tasks. It should be mentioned that this type of assignment does not make the usual computational training tasks obsolete since it is well-recognised in the competence concept that a sound knowledge and skills base is a necessary but not sufficient requirement for a person to be mathematically competent. The examples can also serve further purposes: they can be used to convince colleagues that the pedagogical concept has a real meaning, and they can also be used for competence assessment.

p.strong: Description of an e-learning tutorial in geostatistics delivered at one university and at one company

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Technology in Learning
Author's preference: Oral

In 2011, we started a research study in engineering education aiming to make explicit the assumptions and decisions for the design of digital learning resources that would support learning in both academia and industry. For the purpose of the investigation based on design research methodology, an e-learning tutorial in geostatistics has been designed, in real world settings and in collaboration with instructors from industry and teachers from university. The learning resource has been implemented in parallel with class lectures for blended learning at one company and at one engineering school. The module has been refined iteratively along the process.

The paper is a description of the e-learning module and of its application in academic and corporate contexts. The e-learning resource is a self-paced tutorial which provides basic knowledge in geostatistics prior to learners' participation to class. It involves 2D illustrations, interactive animations, voice-over, exercises, two quizzes, a tracking system that is SCORMTM compliant and other functionalities. Each time, the provision has been adapted to the course constraints of the client institution. In addition, we analyze the concepts in geoscience and their relations (discipline or content knowledge), the way they are usually represented and transmitted to the learners (pedagogical knowledge) and their impact on the design and usage of the e-learning module. To finish, we discuss the choices of technology that have been made to support learning in the particular context of the study (technology affordance).

p.strong: Educating new Global Engineers by re-cycling the old ones

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: The Global Engineer
Author's preference: Oral
"Educating new Global Engineers by re-cycling the old ones"
Abstract

This paper is an examination and distillation of 6-years' experience supervising Work-Based Learning MSc Professional Engineering programme for company-based student in the UK, Indonesia, Angola and Azerbaijan. The student are seeking to become registered as UK Chartered Engineers by undertaking this programme, at the same time as holding down demanding jobs. All of the overseas student workfor Oil and Gas companies - one of the world's truly Global Industries' that need Global Engineers'.

The Engineering Council pioneered the Engineering Gateways' scheme as another route to registration in 2006, with a 3-year pilot programme. In 2010 Aston University decided to offer the programme overseas (as well as the UK) in response to requests from BP. These programme are tailored around each participant's job, and develop a series of Reports for assessment, each addressing a specific themed generic academic module. Professional' Supervision of the MSc is usually carried out by retired or semi-retired Chartered Engineers, who pass on their expertise and experience to today's budding Global Engineers.

The result so far show some fascinating cultural' influences that took time to understand. The participants are all, in the main, mature' individuals who develop unique coping mechanisms to handle job pressures and self-motivation issues. The programme is not for everyone! A rigorous selection process helps us identify those individuals who can cope with this challenging route to CEng registration, through the MSc Professional Engineering approach. These are the Global Engineers of tomorrow.

p.strong: Review of Engineering Mathematics curriculum at UCD in light of qualitative changes in secondary-school mathematics education in IrelandNiall J. English, School of Chemical and Bioprocess Engineering, UCD, Belfield, Dublin 4, Ireland

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Maths in EE
Author's preference: Either

In view of the recent introduction (circa 2010-2012) of the Project Mathematics syllabus for the Irish school-leaving ( Leaving Certificate ) examinations (and subsequent two-year lag before this cohort of student reached university in Ireland and elsewhere), it has become necessary to recast, revise and alter the timing of the engineering-mathematics curriculum at University College Dublin. This paper discusses these necessary changes and curriculum redesign to accommodate student who have been taught mathematics at secondary school in Ireland in a qualitatively different way to more traditional, teacher-led approach in which there is a strong hierarchical taxonomy: the main structural shift at secondary-school level has been towards a more problem-based learning approach. At UCD, changes have resulted in a time-compression and redesign in mathematical coverage in first year in two modules (each 36 lectures and 12 tutorials) whose current syllabuses were revised especially in terms of calculus, vectors and linear algebra to mesh in a more seamless way with the Project Mathematics syllabus. In terms of resultant, knock-on effects on syllabi in subsequent years, the primary changes were in a second-year course on multi-variable calculus, with the placement of other material, such as vector calculus, Fourier analysis and applications to physical problems, placed in a third-year course. Overall, with the very recent implementation of this new engineering-mathematics syllabus, early, informal indications suggest that the redesign has been quite effective in terms of appropriate mapping onto the student school-level mathematics background and abilities, helping with a good transition to university-level mathematics education in Engineering.

p.strong: Evaluating Postgraduate student' Perceptions of ALL: findings from a longitudinal study

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Active Learning
Author's preference: Oral
Gill Cooke, Phillip Lewis, Irene Glendinning Coventry University, Coventry, UK

activities Led Learning (ALL) was introduced in a postgraduate module, Management of Quality, during the 2010-11 academic year designed to improve student engagement. The implementation of ALL centred on a "passport" concept which required the student to engage with the module both prior to and during the contact sessions. This system encouraged more effective engagement, through active participation and interaction during the contact time. student were required to work on pre-determined activities in groups and communicate with other student about what they had learned. Since its' introduction the module has been incrementally refined in response to evidence and feedback. For the first two years the changes were only implemented and evaluated for full time (largely international) student. In the third year, the concept was extended to include part time (predominantly UK student in full-time employment) to explore and evaluate transfer-ability. The part time version was based on the same concept with organisational differences to account for the different delivery timescale. All module iterations were carefully monitored and evaluated using a qualitative research design and anonymous surveys. Findings demonstrated that the increased engagement led to improved student satisfaction and deep learning, achieved through the introduction of constructive alignment between the activities and assessments. The data also demonstrated that the concept could be adapted to suit a different cohort type and delivery schedule.This paper presents the findings from this longitudinal study. The authors believe this concept is transferable to other subjects, institutions and situations to help improve the postgraduate student experience.

p.strong: Multidisciplinary Learning Affordances of a Science-Based Virtual World Environment

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Technology in Learning
Author's preference: Oral

Katrina Nordstr1, Pekka Qvist2, Tuomas Kangasniemi1, Sonja Palom?1, Sebastian Olkinuora1, Marko N?i1, Olli Natri1, Jenni Sepp?n3, Paulus Artimo3, Pekka Joensuu1 1Aalto University, Espoo, 00076 Aalto, Finland, 2Metaverstas Ltd., Turku, Finland, 3Helsinki University, Helsinki, Finland

Virtual world (VW) spaces are the embodiment of future learning environments with user-generated content allowing for the maximization of capacity for iterative design in response to user feedback and changing social, environmental, and educational contexts. VWs have many significant advantages compared to real-life learning spaces, and foster the digital literacies necessary to participate in the evolving workplace or study environment in a modern knowledge-based economy. Accordingly we have designed and tested the instructional use of a virtual laboratory, LabLife3D, in Second Life, to bridge the gap between theory and practice. We have built 5 virtual laboratory exercises in biotechnology and chemistry; a virus isolation experiment, a laboratory safety tutorial, organic chemistry decarboxylation reactions and vacuum distillation, and a molecular biology simulation. We present the design process, the views of student and teachers on barriers and enablers to learning in VWs. Some 40 student took part in the testing and 18 teachers have been interviewed on the role of facilitation and the ease of use of digital technology in teaching and learning. We have also experimented with collecting quantitative data on student decisions in the virtual environment. Such data consists of clicks and events triggered by the clicks, time tags of all the actions, compositions of the used substances, and needed actions. student gave very positive feedback on the learning experiences, but teachers were more hesitant to embrace new technology. Thus, there is a need for generating clear instructional "toolboxes" and facilitation roles for teachers in digital environments.

p.strong: Training of Academic Staff for Engineering Education: A Programme for Developing Teaching and Learning at University

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Continuing Engineering Education and Lifelong learning
Author's preference: Oral

Technische Universit?Berlin (TUB), one of the biggest technical university in Germany, is qualifying about 30 000 student. Hundreds of student in lectures and courses make teaching and learning often ineffective and unsatisfying. This situation is very demanding for the teaching staff, the more that most of them have neither previous didactic nor pedagogic training for their teaching tasks.

Therefore, we train teaching staff at TUB to develop their teaching competences. In addition to about 300 full-time professors, it comprises nearly 2500 research and teaching assistants, normally contracted for 5 years. Besides working on their doctoral thesis, they are obliged to teach at least 4 hours per week.

The crucial question is: How can teaching staff be trained motivational and effectively for innovative teaching formats to foster interactive learning in this environment? How a new teaching and learning culture can be implemented successfully?

Our solution is to develop teaching competences theoretically and practically. We focus on improving the quality of teaching and learning as well as the satisfaction of teachers and learners. Our training programme teaching and learning (accredited by the German Association for Academic Development) is complemented by tailor-made offers according to teachers individual needs. The long-term goal is to qualify all teaching staff during all phases of their teaching career corresponding with the impact of life long learning and professional supportive structures at university and in faculties.
The paper will describe and analyse the curriculum for the qualification. A desirable brand of competences in teaching-profile will be outlined.

p.strong: Evaluation of Innovative Teaching and Learning Projects in Engineering Education

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Quality Assurance and Accreditation
Author's preference: Oral

The evaluation of lectures, exercise classes and tutorials is getting more and more important in the university context due to quality aspects. This is particularly true for tu wimi plus, which is one among 8 project-lines at TU Berlin, funded by the German Federal Ministry of Education and Research to provide better study conditions and to improve the quality of teaching and learning. Currently, it provides support for 7 research and teaching assistants in 9 innovative teaching projects at thematically very different chairs (e.g. electrical engineering, mathematics or mechanics) on how to design and implement subject-specific teaching curricula in the respective fields. In order to augment interdisciplinary and student-centred approach, a variety of instruments is used such as the development of innovative teaching and learning projects, within which problem-oriented or e-learning-supported methods are applied more frequently.

However, when it comes to evaluation we need to find out how didactically innovative teaching and learning projects should be evaluated and how they are perceived by student compared to ex-cathedra teaching.

Addressing these questions, we developed a questionnaire which matches the learning objectives of the lectures. It focuses on a self-evaluation of the learning activities student perform in class rather than concentrating on their satisfaction with the lecture. The effectiveness of this method was tested in a pilot study in4 of our teaching projects during the winter term 2013/2014.
The paper describes the concept of the questionnaire and its sections. First findings of our pilot study will be presented during the conference.

p.strong: Early Career Female Engineers: Influences and Challenges

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Issues of Gender and Diversity
Author's preference: Oral
John Davies1, Abbie Jones2 1Coventry University, Coventry, UK, 2WSP, Birmingham, UK

The gender balance within engineering is a current concern, particularly in the UK. There is a great deal of interest in determining why fewer girls take STEM subjects in education and in identifying barriers to females studying and practising engineering.

This study chose as its focus early career female engineers, typically between graduation and professional qualification. It was felt that this group gave a particularly valuable perspective, since at this important early stage in their careers they are able to recall key influences on career decision-making, and pinpoint with fresh eyes significant challenges in the profession.

Ten participants were interviewed as part of the study. Key themes were developed by the researcher throughout the study, focusing on the main influences on participants' choice of engineering as a subject and career, and the current challenges they face today.

This paper describes the study, and presents the perspectives, ideas and recommendations of the early career female engineers interviewed. Key findings are that participants were largely influenced in their choice of engineering by family or personal experiences, but generally felt let down by the careers advice, and awareness of the engineering industry, at school. Many participants felt that stereotyped images of engineers still exist outside the industry. They also indicated that the type of engineering company greatly affects the type of challenges a female engineers might face. Participants felt that active promotion of STEM subjects within education is important, but not necessarily aimed only at girls.

p.strong: Supporting Engineering student at the start of their university course: an industry-university collaboration to provide tailored online mathematics resources.

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Maths in EE
Author's preference: Oral
Stephen Lee1, Michael Peters2 1Mathematics in Education and Industry, Trowbridge, UK, 2Aston University, Birmingham, UK

Mathematics in Education and Industry (MEI), a small, independent, charitable UK curriculum development body, collaborated with Aston University to establish a tailored online support course of mathematics materials for several groups of undergraduate engineering student. These student were studying for a Foundation Degree in either Power Engineering or Gas Transmission. They were heterogeneous in terms of their skills and knowledge of mathematics. Many of them had not studied mathematics for some years and others expressed concerns about the level of mathematics they would encounter at Aston University. student would access the online materials in the weeks prior to beginning lectures at the university and they continued to have access throughout their first year of their study. This approach was taken in order to reduce student anxiety and to manage their expectations of studying mathematics at university level.

This paper gives an outline of the creation of the mathematics support course' produced within a Moodle Virtual Learning Environment, before detailing the student who used the materials. Feedback from the project is presented and comparisons made with feedback received from a similar pilot course for STEM student.

p.strong: Upgraded Practical Training for student of Nuclear Sciences at CTU-FNSPE

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Physics in EE
Author's preference: Oral

Ladislav Musilek, Jan Cepila, Katerina Cubova, Rudolf Klepacek, Dusan Kobylka, Petr Prusa Czech Technical University in Prague, Faculty of Nuclear Sciences and Physical Engineering, Praha 1, Czech Republic

The CTU-FNSPE in Prague is the only university institution in the country that teaches and develops a broad range of studies in the field of nuclear sciences. The Faculty has its own small nuclear reactor and a small tokamak. The rapid development of nuclear physics and chemistry, and of their applications, and also ongoing efforts achieve the highest possible levels of nuclear and radiation safety, have led to a need for advanced practical training for student. A project was therefore applied for within the framework of the Prague Adaptability Operational Programme, supported by European funding. This project aims to improve the quality of studies in educational institutions in Prague, and has been used to innovate the laboratories for practical training of student at five departments of the Faculty. A total of 23 exercises for measuring and evaluating various quantities have been upgraded or newly prepared, ranging from the characteristics of nuclear reactor kinetics, through the design of the electronic circuits for nuclear measurements, ionising radiation spectrometry, measurement of the absorbed dose, detection of radioactive contamination, to topics such as the use of radiation diffraction in the study of materials. This paper deals with the system for practical training of student of nuclear sciences at the Faculty, and shows how the result of the project have been helping to refine the practical training of student. The practical exercises will be offered both for student of FNSPE and other educational institutions, and for in-service training and life-long learning.

p.strong: The application of Repertory Grid interview method for improving the identification and understanding of competencies required for engineering practice

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Education al Research Methods
Author's preference: Oral
Mohd Nazri Mahmud, Tom Ridgman University of Cambridge, Cambridge, UK

Educating engineers through outcome-based education requires the identification of competencies required for engineering practice. One of the ways in which such competencies can be identified is by engaging with practising engineers through interviews. During interviews, engineers are asked to describe competencies required for various aspects of engineering practice. However, there are at least two main limitations in such interviews. First, practising engineers often find it difficult to articulately describe and explain part of competencies that are implicit [1]. Second, interviewers often find it difficult to accurately interpret words and phrases used for competency descriptions [2]. Interview methods that can improve the identification and understanding of competencies required have therefore been called for.

This paper describes an interview method that can help interviewers in identifying part of competencies that are implicit, and in interpreting words and phrases used by interviewees. We adopt, adapt and apply the Repertory Grid Technique (RGT) method for interviewing practising engineers. It is found that such approach can facilitate the elicitation of competencies that are implicit to the interviewees. It can also help in accessing personal meanings of words and phrases used by them.

p.strong: Teachas you preach: Professionalizing teaching assistants in engineering within the 2020 context

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Active Learning
Author's preference: Oral

Inge Van Hemelrijck1 ,2, Elsje Londers1 ,2, Yolande Berbers1, Laura De Geyter1 1Faculty of Engineering, KU Leuven, Leuven, Belgium, 2Leuven Engineering and Science Education Center (LESEC), Leuven, Belgium

At KU Leuven, practice sessions are traditionally the responsibility of teaching assistants, typically PhD student with an additional teaching assignment. The Faculty of Engineering attaches great importance to the role of the TAs since practice sessions are an indispensable tool in a student's learning process. After all, these additional contact moments serve as the necessary bridge between the theory taught during the lectures and the practice these student will face during their exams and in their future careers. Since many teaching assistants struggled with coaching these practice sessions, the Faculty of Engineering at the KU Leuven introduced an educational training programme for PhD student in 2005. In 2013, this programme was evaluated through a questionnaire of 400 TAs, combined with focus groups with some 20 assistants of 5 deliberately chosen courses. These revealed the specific needs of these teaching assistants that will constitute the building blocks of the new training programme.

In this paper, we will present the blueprint for the new TA training that will draw on the 'teach as you preach' principle, thus enabling the TAs to get acquainted with new didactical techniques that will enhance and facilitate the learning process of their student. This programme will consist of a number of sessions that revolve around different teaching formats, designed to reflect the educational practice of the TAs. These training sessions will focus on the principles of flipped teaching, dealing with frequently occurring problems, activating student and the implementation of modern technology in the teaching practice.

p.strong: A Engineering Imagination Training Paradigm based on Conceptual Combination Theory

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Continuing Engineering Education and Lifelong learning
Author's preference: Poster

Ruey-Yun Horng3, Ching-Wen Wang2, Chien-Tao Li1 1National Chiao Tung University, Hsinchu, Taiwan, 2National Chung Hsing University, Taichung, Taiwan, 3National Chung Hsing University, Taichung, Taiwan

This study aims to propose a conceptual combination training paradigm for enhancing engineering imagination. Conceptual combination refers to joining of two or more than two concepts to produce new concepts. It is proposed to be the cognitive process underlying human imagination. However, not all ideas produced from conceptual combination are original. Factors that increase the chance of producing original ideas from conceptual combination include: 1. a random process to attract disparate and remote concepts to be considered together, 2. the concepts are conceived in a relatively abstract level, 3. The type of interpretation used to combine the concepts meaningfully, and 4. The selection criteria so that original ideas can be retained for further consideration. For enhancing engineering creativity, a priming paradigm that incorporates the above four factors is proposed. In the training, participants will be instructed about different types of interpretation that can be used to combine two unrelated concepts. Then, several sessions of conceptual combination practice would be administered. During practice, noun-noun pairs that are formed by unrelated concepts of different ontological categories are presented, and participants have to generate a new idea using a specific type of interpretation. The noun-noun pairs can vary freely in terms of the level of abstractness, or domain knowledge. It is expected that the training will facilitate the random process in participants thinking, and their ability to join two or more than two remote concepts together. It is predicted that such practice would prime for more original ideas in engineering design tasks.

p.strong: Industrial Leadership Requirements- qualifications promoting competitiveness

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Curriculum Development
Author's preference: Oral

European higher engineering education has a solid tradition in imparting an education that equips engineering graduates with a broad base of knowledge, skills and attitudes pivotal to success in industrial processes. And yet, despite the changing global conditions calling for new approach to industrial leadership, leadership training as part of higher education, especially in technical fields, has remained unappreciated. To better meet industrial competence requirements in engineering education, the Accreditation Board of Engineering and Technology has recently extended its accreditation criteria to leadership, "leading engineering endeavours" but concrete efforts to conceptualize effective leadership and define leader competences still remain modest, hindering the related curriculum development. This paper sheds light on industrial leadership requirements and the related implications for pedagogy integrating leadership skills and competences into higher engineering education. The present study embarked on a quantitative empirical effort to identify leader requirements in engineering communities. Specifically, the study divided leader qualifications into six categories: 1) substantive knowledge, 2) personality (motifs), 3) emotive skills, 4) communication skills, 5) cultural skills, and 6) values and attitudes. Under such a definition of leader capabilities, leader qualifications were further divided into 80 skills, abilities or personality traits.

The result from a sample of 462 respondents to an online survey indicate that such emotive skills and personality dimensions that form the foundation for self-leadership are prioritized highest in leader evaluations, both as viewed by managers and subordinates.

p.strong: PLACIS: Active learning and teaching through industrial, international and at-a-distance collaborative projects

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Active Learning
Author's preference: Poster
Alexis Fran?s, Antoine Lanthony SUPMECA, Saint-Ouen, France

PLACIS is a project funded by the French National Agency for Research under "Investments for the future" program. PLACIS started in September 2012 and will finish in August 2016. The project was presented at the 41st SEFI Conference in the paper "PLACIS: International Inter-University Collaborative Training Platform in Systems Engineering". Since this paper, PLACIS gained in maturity: new student' projects, new partners, but also development of new tools and use of PLACIS as a base for a new Erasmus+ project.

All these aspects make us able to see the first achievements of what is the main PLACIS goal: not only to train student to become classic engineers, but to train student to become systems engineers, able to understand multidisciplinary issues, to work in teams, with people from different cultures and, more generally, to be actors of their curricula and to move easily in today's and tomorrow's industrial world.

Moreover, one of our goals is to engage into active training of teachers, because we think that trying to reach the student without trying to reach the teachers could lead to failures. This will be done in the new Erasmus+ project.

Our poster presents PLACIS through its objectives, paths and tools, ongoing development and main result. It makes clear how PLACIS projects work, what student gain from them and what will be the future steps for PLACIS.

p.strong: Developing an Online Course: Challenges and Enablers

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Technology in Learning
Author's preference: Oral

p.em: Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA, USA

body.p: Innovations in teaching methods and educational technology, combined with the advent of Internet, advancement in infrastructure that allows for connectivity at a global level, and developments in open access, have been leading scholars to rethink the learning process and the opportunities for new educational settings worldwide. Technology now allows professors to transfer even more information outside the classroom enabling them to flip their classroom and use in-class time in a different manner. Building on these trends, MIT established the Office of Digital Learning (ODL) in 2012. The mission of the ODL is to help the MIT community lead the world in education by creating, using and levering learning technology and digital instructional content. MITx is a constituent organization of ODL, aiming to support development of MIT-quality online courses, and to further understanding of best practices in digital learning. Some of the online courses developed by MITx have been designed as Massive Online Open Courses (MOOCs) offered to a global audience, while others are still only used within MIT to enhance residential education. Through the end of 2013, 15 MOOCs were offered globally through the EdX platform and 23 online courses were offered at a residential level within the flipped-classroom framework. Through this study we hope to understand the process faculty members and their teams go through while developing their online courses, and identify challenges and enablers. Data stemming from 10 faculty members, research staff and graduate student who participated in the online course development are presented in this paper.

p.strong: Does increasing student activities and reducing lecturing improve learning outcome in courses?

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Active Learning
Author's preference: Oral

Aalborg University has used Problem Based Learning since 1974. The primary model is big projects (15 ECTS) each semester solved in student groups. The rest of the study time the student follow courses where exercises is solved together in the student groups to enhance peer learning in courses. Traditionally courses have been 50% lecturing and 50% exercises. As an experiment it was decided to change that in the autumn 2013 trying to activate the student more by decreasing the lecturing and use more time and effort on exercises followed up by a reflective dialogue with the student about lessons learnt. The setup of the traditional and the new version of the course is explained and the effects of the change analyzed by comparing two cohorts of first semester Software Engineering and Computer Science student. The course is aimed at improving the potential of freshmen student project work helping them to develop their skills in cooperation, learning and project management. After the semester each student group write a process analysis where they reflect on these issues and come up with ideas to improve their performance in the next project. The effect of the changes in the course is analyzed by comparing both the written Process Analysis and individual answers from the student to relevant exam questions taken from a written exam of the course. The result show that less lecturing doesn't decrease the student's skills in the subjects and more exercises and reflections don't improve the skills either.

p.strong: Achieving generic competences through a cross-disciplinary research based course in Arctic Technology

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Active Learning
Author's preference: Oral
Gunvor M. Kirkelund1, Claus T. Hansen2, Pernille E. Jensen1 1DTU Civil Engineering, Techincal University of Denmark, Kgs. Lyngby, Denmark, 2DTU Mechanical Engineering, Kgs. Lyngby, Denmark

A cross-disciplinary research based 15 ECTS course in Arctic Technology is offered to engineering student regardless of study programme. The main focus for the student is on a specific research project formed around a 3 weeks field period in Greenland. The teaching activities focus on developing engineering competences such as project planning and management, working in a different culture as well as both oral and written communication skills, while the student are studying a topic relevant to their study programme in the new Arctic setting. The student work through 3 semesters with their chosen project, with preparation of field work in the spring, practical field work in the summer and project work and reporting in the autumn. It is essential that the student take ownership of and manage their own project, with the course responsible as a guide to the Arctic context and the project supervisor as the scientific topic specific guide. During the course, the student are offered different feedback options on their work and progress. To be able to assess all student, the learning objectives and feedback are generically focussed rather than topic specific. It is clearly seen by the learning outcome and assessment that student who use the feedback options actively are more successful in achieving both the scientific and the generic competences than the student who do not. The student evaluate the course as being highly motivating for further learning and they get confident by successfully having executed a research based project in a new context.

p.strong: Developing and Conducting Entrepreneurship Education for Engineering student- Lessons learned whileeducating student through entrepreneurship

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Curriculum Development
Author's preference: Either
Abstract theme: Curriculum development

As a natural reaction to the increased societal and governmental interest in entrepreneurship, the offering, conducting and research of entrepreneurship education has become a focal pointat university.

The purpose of this paper is to put the topic of entrepreneurship education into an engineering educational context and propose an answer the question "How can entrepreneurship be taught to engineering student?" This paper is primarily written for other lectures with the purpose of sharing experiences in an attempt to further develop the field of entrepreneurship education in engineering departments and secondary as food for thought for decision makers regarding curriculum content in the aforementioned departments
In order to investigate the research question a literature review is done combined with an prospective case study, serving both as an illustrative case and as a source of empirical data.

There are numerous ways of developing and conducting entrepreneurship education varying in purpose ansform. Education through entrepreneurship has proven purposeful in terms of developing student likely to display entrepreneurial behaviour in the future, but educating through entrepreneurship poses a number of challenges both in relation to the frames of higher educational institutes and in terms of facilitating group of causal trained student through an effectuation process.

The paper at hand testify to the value of entrepreneurship education but at the same time shed light on some of the challenges associated with it. Owning the question of how to best solve the problems?
Papertype: Empirical paper
Session Format: Research Discussion Session

p.strong: Experiential learning as a method to enhance experiential teaching

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Active Learning
Author's preference: Oral
Pernille Andersson, Claus Thorp Hansen Technical University of Denmark, Kgs. Lyngby Copenhagen, Denmark

Crucial for success in Engineering Education (EE) to educate engineers equipped with the knowledge, skills and attitudes they need to meet the challenges they will face as professionals is that faculty has the right competences to, and understanding about, how to enhance learning. One of the roads forward is to use student centred and active teaching methods. Even if the development of EE in this direction has been going on for several years, still it is hard to make a sustain shift in learning culture at many university. A teacher training programme for experienced teachers has recently been developed at DTU where the aim is through experiential learning learn the participants about and how to use experiential learning in courses. The overall strategy follows the steps in the learning circle of Kolb in a pure way, staring with the participants' analysis of their own teaching experiences and of their student' perception of the teaching provided. This is followed by theoretical input about teaching and learning in higher education in the stage of abstract conceptualisation. On the background of those stages the participants construct a new course design and suggest an implementation plan of the revisions. In this paper we describe this new teacher training programme. The participants' experiences and learning outcomes will also be discussed mirrored in what research in the field. Finally, we reflect upon whether a teacher training programme of this kind fulfils its overall purpose to impact development of teaching practice and to what extent.

p.strong: How inquiry project-based instruction affect the vocational high school student' learning performance

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Active Learning
Author's preference: Poster

Shiang-Yao Liu1, Chien-Cheng Tsai2, Chi-Ming Lai3 1Graduate Institute of Science Education, National Taiwan Normal University, Taipei, Taiwan, 2Division of Civil Engineering, National Tainan Vocational High School, Tainan, Taiwan, 3Department of Civil Engineering, National Cheng Kung University, Tainan, Taiwan

This study is part of a collaborative program between university and vocational senior high school for improving teaching and learning in engineering courses. One class of student who attended the course of "surveying practicum" was observed to evaluate the effectiveness of teaching improvement. In the practicum, student are usually guided to follow the standard operational process or cook-book like protocol to make rigid and precise measurement. After gaining exposure to project-based instructional strategies, the teacher designed a series of surveying tasks, including traverse surveying and longitudinal section surveying that allow student to discuss the methods and procedures with peers and find out the resolutions on their own. Each group of student then presented their design and result after carrying out surveys on campus. It was fairly surprising to the teacher that student generated two effective methods with one similar to that in the textbook and the other one new. Multiple sources of quantitative and qualitative data were collected during the course to explore any changes on student' views of scientific inquiry and perceptions of learning. Analyses of the pre- and post- tests collected from the modified Views of Science Inquiry (VOSI) questionnaire indicated that student' understanding about scientific inquiry has improved after the course (average score increased from 7.45 to 9.28 based on the scoring criteria developed in this study). Qualitative data through triangulation revealed that student find this innovative instruction enjoyable and experiential because it can initiate self-directed learning and creativity.

p.strong: The effects of imagination on engineering design performance

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Education al Research Methods
Author's preference: Poster
Ching-Wen Wang2, Chia-Ying Lu1, Ruey-Yun Horng3 1National Chung Hsing University, Taichung, Taiwan, 2National Taiwan University, Taipei, Taiwan, 3National Chiao Tung University, Hsinchu, Taiwan

Variable needs and advancement in technology promote the continuous innovations on technological products. As imagination is the key component in creativity, how to facilitate imagination in product design and development becomes an important part of engineering design education. This study defines imagination in terms of the ability for conceptual combination, and examines the role of imagination on engineering design performance through a creativity competition. There were three stages in the creativity competition. Three scholars and two design experts evaluated the competition, and the evaluation criteria included innovation, subject conceptualization and content clarity, as well as strategy for competition and creative marketing. In the first stage, 120 dyads participated. They were asked to creatively conceptualize three topics. In the second stage, 45 dyads were chosen and participated in a one-day imagination workshop. The training included imagination and conceptual combination, design concept and application, and case studies on imagination and innovation. These groups were asked to submit their proposals on a new innovative product or marketing strategy. In the third stage, 15 dyads were chosen and presentedtheir proposals. The participants of this study were the 45 dyads in the second stage, whom were asked to take the imagination measure. The result found that participants' imagination ability had significant role on the design performance, and the 15 dyads that went into the final competition showed higher imagination. Therefore, the study suggests that engineering design education should emphasize the training on creativity and imagination and include them in professional classes.

p.strong: Developing a Creativity-enhanced PBL for Inspiring Future Hydraulic Engineers

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Curriculum Development
Author's preference: Oral

Ya-Ting Yang1, Hsiao-Wen Wang2 1The Institute of Education, National Cheng-Kung University, Tainan, Taiwan, 2Department of Hydraulic and Ocean Engineering, National Cheng-Kung University, Tainan, Taiwan

Taiwan is in a seismically active zone and frequently experiences tropical storms and large variations in precipitation. In order to prevent and manage the consequences of earthquakes, typhoons, and excessive rainfall, hydraulic engineering education in Taiwan must be directed towards practical and relevant learning while also fostering higher order thinking skills, such as creativity and problem solving. Since project-based learning (PBL) provides contextualized and authentic learning, which has been demonstrated to foster higher order thinking while promoting acquisition of content-area knowledge, this project applies PBL to hydraulic engineering education. A PBL curriculum was designed to emphasize real-world problems, which enabled student to actively explore the project for the cause and process, to explain the cause and effect and solution, and to extensively apply the knowledge they learn. By doing so, this curriculum can enhance learning motivation and academic performance. In this study, we adopted creativity-enhanced PBL with the aim to foster the creativity and problem-solving skills necessary for innovation and excellence in the learners future professional careers as hydraulic engineers. The study will adopt a pretest and post-test quasi-experimental design. Over a 16-week intervention, the control group will receive traditional instruction while the experimental group will receive PBL instruction. Analysis of covariance (ANCOVA) will be used to compare the learning outcomes of the two research groups. This study will explore how different teaching strategies influence student creativity and problem-solving skills and, at the same time, hydraulic engineering knowledge.
Keyword: hydraulic engineering, project-based learning, creativity, problem-solving.

p.strong: Engineering and network analysis

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Active Learning
Author's preference: Oral
Rossella Pozzi, Carlo No, Fernanda Strozzi LIUC University, Castellanza, Italy

Reports on the future of engineering by the National Academy of Engineering describe the economy in which engineers will work as strongly influenced by the global marketplace for engineering services. Globalization together with more and more frequent interaction will drive to increasing complexity the systems industrial engineers will deal with. Nowadays, systems as well as communities and computer networks are represented as complex networks, and complex networks theory represents a tool for effectively studying and understanding them.

The present work presents the learning experience of four work groups of Engineering student of LIUC University facing network analysis for the first time. In particular, each work group is free to apply the network analysis to a topic belonging to its area of interest. In order to respond the research questions proposed, each group apply the most suitable measures of the complex networks theory, and the obtained result are outlined. Last, the present paper points out the managerial implications recommended by the work groups, advised by the authors, due to the network analysis result.

p.strong: Authentic Assessments of Teaching Skills

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Quality Assurance and Accreditation
Author's preference: Oral
Thomas Olsson1, Bj??Badersten2 1Faculty of Engineering, Lund University, Lund, Sweden, 2Faculty of Social Sciences, Lund University, Lund, Sweden

In this Research Discussion Session we would like to discuss a collaborative project, that is carried out by the Faculty of Engineering and the Faculty of Social Sciences at Lund University, with the ambition to develop research based supplementary methods to evaluate and assess teachers' teaching skills. We are well aware that such methods can only demonstrate selected perspectives of the complexity of teaching skills, but could form an important attempt to capture a more authentic picture of parts of what represents good teaching.

We build the development on our research about rewarding and assessing teaching skills and pedagogical competence (Olsson and Rox?008; Olsson and Rox?012; Olsson and Rox?013; Larsson, Anderberg and Olsson 2014). We will examine the possibility to develop tests based on case studies. It could be cases concerning different types of problematic teaching situations or aspects of evaluation and assessment. Another suggestion could be analyses of authentic teaching situations (described or filmed). Further proposals to investigate could be planning of teaching and learning activities (at programme level, course level or class level); discussions about learning hurdles (Shulman 1986) and the content of teaching (what, how, why. We will also consider the possibility of combining a specific task with a short presentation (in an authentic lesson/lecture form).

Our initial draft is to build assessment of teaching skills on reflection in action (Sch??983) and actions that question current assumptions and conditions for the implementation of teaching (Argyris and Sch??974).

p.strong: Enabling and supporting quality assurance in a major engineering faculty'

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Quality Assurance and Accreditation
Author's preference: Oral
Val?e Wyns, Elsje Londers, Inge Van Hemelrijck, Yolande Berbers KULeuven, Leuven, Belgium

The Faculty of Engineering Science at the KU Leuven invests greatly in quality assurance. However, because of the complex nature of the faculty, which comprises 22 programme of varying level, student numbers and characteristics, a thoroughly efficient approach to quality assurance is necessary. The paper presented will focus on the process of formulating learning outcomes and performing parallel curriculum mappings throughout the engineering faculty.

The education staff members formulated a three-step approach to improve uniformity of learning outcomes and ECTS-files, resulting in the harmonization of the curriculum. The first step consists of translating the learning outcomes of each programme into the same framework', namely ACQA (Academic Competences and Quality Assurance). Educational developers assist each programme in reformulating their learning outcomes. The second step consists of an extensive online curriculum mapping, registering to which outcomes each course contributes. The mapping provides a view of the presence of attention paid to each learning outcome. A third step entails a thorough check of all ECTS-files. Each professor receives personalized suggestions on how they can improve their files. We compiled a customized checklist so the check-up can proceed as fluently as possible.

After these three steps, the review of the faculty's curriculum is facilitated greatly by the synchronized learning outcomes and the easily accessible curriculum mappings. Adopting the ACQA-framework also proved to be a starting point for the exchange of experiences and reflection by professors and teaching assistants.

p.strong: Situation in Engineering university of Applied Science in Oulu and Eindhoven to Teach Methods to Achieve Innovations in Businesses

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Curriculum Development
Author's preference: Oral
Hannu P?alo1, Hay Geraedts1 1Oulu University of Applied Sciences, Oulu, Finland, 2Fontys University of Applied Sciences Eindhoven, Eindhoven, The Netherlands

p.b: Situation in Engineering Education in Oulu and Eindhoven to Teach Methods to Achieve Innovations in Businesses

body.p: Hannu P?alo and Hay Geraedts
Hannu P?alo, Oulu University of applied Sciences, Oulu, Finland, hannu.paatalo@oamk.fi
Hay Geraedts, Fontys University of applied Sciences, Eindhoven, the Netherlands, hgm.geraedts@fontys.nl

The importance of teaching engineering student innovation development is commonly clearly understood. It is essential to achieve products which are attractive and profitable in the market. To achieve this, an institute of engineering education has to provide student with needed knowledge, skills and attitudes including both technical and business orientation. This is important especially for SME's.

Traditionally, education of engineering provides student with basic understanding how to solve common technical problems. However companies need wider view to achieve new products. university of Applied Science in Oulu and Eindhoven want to research what is the today's educational situation for this aim, to find criteria to improve the content of the educational system, and to improve the educational system.

Important stakeholders are teachers and student within the institute but also key-persons in companies. The research is realized by questionnaires and interviews from which a current situation can be found. The research will also include the opinion of management who give possibilities to change the curriculum. By this research more insight will be presented about how to re-design a current curriculum.The research will act as basis for this discussion in SEFI-conference about formulating a curriculum that includes elements for wide-ranging knowledge and skills to achieve innovations especially in SME's.

p.strong: Industry and engineering education interacting in an interregional project - a Flanders' perspective

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Continuing Engineering Education and Lifelong learning
Author's preference: Either
Jos Knockaert1, Geert De Lepeleer2, Tony Stevens2, Philippe Saey2 1Ghent University, Ghent, Belgium, 2KU Leuven, Leuven, Belgium

The Interreg-IVa 2-Seas project i-MOCCA ("interregional MObility and Competence Centres in Automation") concentrates on two fast evolving topics: industrial data communication and embedded control. Both require high-end training of practising engineers in industry and demonstrators illustrating proof-of-principle of emerging technology. The i-MOCCA project aims to develop competence centres in different university in the coastal regions of the UK, France and Flanders, Belgium. The "triple helix model" incorporating university and knowledge centres, government and professional organizations, and the private (industry) sector, is regarded by the EU as very important for the "knowledge based economy". From the beginning, the i-MOCCA project partners have established numerous contacts with the private sector via courses, MSc final year projects delivering use cases for industry and for? relevant laboratory exercises, lectures, ... Cooperation with government and professional organizations is established by funding, dissemination, broad communication, Essential for interregional cooperation between the i-MOCCA partners is the use of "common basic equipment", facilitating efficient cooperation and joint development. This enables staff mobility avoiding movement of equipment. On "internal i-MOCCA conferences" intermediate work packages and result are discussed. On more informal "technical days", work in progress (demonstrators, measurements, ...) is shown and discussed in an interactive way. Finished courses are exchanged (and used on the same equipment), and - if relevant - taught to each other. In the full paper, the above mentioned items are discussed in detail. Industry participation, the numbers of reached engineers, the influence on curriculum development, and emerging student exchanges between project partners are also presented.

p.strong: Design of an interdisciplinary engineering elective scoped around collaboration with Small Medium Sized enterprises (SME)

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Industry involvement in EE
Author's preference: Oral
Nynne Christiansen, Maja Pontoppidan, Mai-Mai Ulrich The Technical University of Denmark, Ballerup, Denmark

DTU Diplom a department of the Technical University of Denmark, educating industry oriented Bachelors of Engineering. One of the goals is to strengthen the collaboration with small and medium-sized enterprises (SME's). Some of the traditional barriers for industry collaboration, especially with SMEs, are difference in time horizon and the difference between the high-tech research case that university look for, and the practical often low-tech solutions that the businesses are looking for.

In designing the course SME Innovation and Intrapreneurship that focus especially on small and micro-sized companies, we have tried to create a match between the company need for short, result oriented innovation projects and the structured professional and interdisciplinary learning goals for a future bachelor of engineering. The course is structured around a shorter project-period of challenging the problem proposed by the company and building the relations among the student necessary to generate innovation and a longer project period dedicated solving the engineering challenge as well as merging the commercial and technical aspects of the innovation process.

We have used the CDIO (Conceive-Design-Implement-Operate) pedagogical framework to design the project. The paper includes considerations on design and experiences with SME collaboration running the first course this spring, where the most important learnings are:

ul.li: Companies and projects should be chosen carefully, and expectation adjustment is essential.
It is a benefit for the student to get to work in an interdisciplinary context.
A sponsorship fee raises the engagement for the University, Company. It is necessary to improve the Student sense of obligation

p.strong: Higher Education Research and Engineering Education Research: Comparative Perspectives

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Education al Research Methods
Author's preference: Oral
Lars Geschwind1, Anette Kolmos2 1KTH Royal Institute of Technology, Stockholm, Sweden, 2Aalborg University, Aalborg, Denmark

Higher education is a sector of growing importance in many societies, which is one of the reasons why it increasingly has found itself the object of research the last decades. Consequently, the number of publications including e.g. peer reviewed journals and meeting places such as conferences and seminars have increased dramatically. Engineering education, as one of the major sub-fields within higher education has, similar to other professional fields, developed its own journals, meeting places and traditions. Both fields have been described as interdisciplinary or multidisciplinary comprising of a mix of disciplinary perspectives and approach. However, increasingly the fields have been established, not only in terms of journals and conferences, but also shown in chairs, dedicated research units etc. In this paper we compare these two different yet related research fields: higher education research and engineering education research. We ask the following research questions: Which research issues are in focus? Which theories and methods are used? How are the result reported? What is the relation to educational practice? We will build our analytical model on developed taxonomies and an analysis of journals, which we have adjusted to the empirical field of both higher education and engineering education. We have chosen four leading journals representing the two fields and analyse the last ten latest online published articles in 2013. The preliminary result indicate differences in the theoretical approach, instrument development, and closeness to the empirical field and impact for practice.

p.strong: Tuition fees and attractiveness of engineering education

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: The Attractiveness of Engineering
Author's preference: Oral
Katriina Schrey-Niemenmaa1, Mervyn Jones2 1Helsinki Metropolia University of Applied Sciences, Helsinki, Finland, 2Imperial College London, London, UK

Who should pay for university tuition? What is the effect of tuition fees on the attractiveness and effectiveness of engineering education? What is the role of fees in the financing of university? How do fees match with the principles of equal opportunities? There are very different practices in collecting tuition fees in different countries in Europe, and even more in the world. Perhaps one extent is Finland, where all the tuition leading to degree is free to all the student and does not depended of their origin. At the other might be the UK where a European student is responsible for paying annual tuition fees of 6k-9k GBP and overseas student a significantly higher rate. In US, Asian and Australian institutions a wide range of fees exists. From a student's viewpoint the total financial load is also depended on the support systems - grants, vouchers, loans and taxation. From university view tuition fees are part of the total financing. In this paper the practices in different countries are discussed. We will focus on items such as, how the fees influence the motivation of studies, how that affects the study possibilities for European student - and for student from further away and finally how fees might affect the quality of teaching and learning. What does this do for the internationalisation of university? Are student selected by talent, money or nationality? An insight comes from a study of Finland with the United Kingdom and a global comparison.

p.strong: The Improvement of Engineering Education Quality Assurance in China

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Quality Assurance and Accreditation
Author's preference: Oral
Yangqiong Qiu, Hanbing Kong Zhejiang University, Zhejiang Province, China

China is cultivating most engineers around the world, almost 90% of Chinese university have established engineering programme. The concern of engineering education quality assurance is becoming the second main factor along with government policy in this flatten world . Recently China has obtained provisional status of Washington Accord, which encourages the development of the accreditation system in engineering education in China. Chinese government strongly encourages the cooperation between university and industries, both in the cultivation of engineers and the education quality assurance practice. Chinese Education Ministry has launched the Excellent Engineers Training Programs with other departments of the government and engineering societies since 2010. This program sets different categories and multi-scale criteria to prepare engineering talents. This paper discusses the progress in engineering education accreditation system in China, and then explores engineering qualification system from UK, continental Europe and US, concluded with some suggestion about further improvement about quality assurance of engineering education in China.

p.strong: Learning Spatial Visualization: Beyond Drills and into Early Mastery

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Curriculum Development
Author's preference: Oral
Emily Farrar, Olufunmilayo Adebayo, Rick Evans, Traci Nathans-Kelly, Tyi McCray Cornell University, Ithaca, NY, USA

student entering university-level engineering programs must be adept at spatial-visualization and reasoning. To raise the performance of first-year student and , the Cornell University Engineering Success (CUES) program used the NSF ENGAGE curriculum to introduce spatial visualization basics. The result were strong, with an overall 13% improvement in tested skills. However, our aims were more ambitious.

Our teaching team believed that skills application in authentic spatial-visualization projects would provide deeper learning, applicable toward school and engineering work. Student teams worked with biomedical researchers who asked for professional-level visualizations. We employed an action-research methodology (observations, journals, expert responses, and e-portfolios), tracking their acquisition of spatial concepts, representations, and critical stances. student evidenced knowledge through their innovative use of support tools and technology to create insightful visualizations of complex engineering data and reliably model biomedical mechanisms relevant to human disease. They also demonstrated critical stances by utilizing appropriate, specific and relevant spatial visualization skills to most effectively communicate each engineering concept. Through peer evaluations, student were also able to identify and critique the use of specific spatial skills by other student teams during project presentations.

We will discuss our result which were documented through both qualitative and quantitative methods. Finally, we plan to bring suggestions as to how this approach could transform current drill and demonstrate approach, serving as a model for the enhancement of similar courses at other institutions.
