Our hope was to give student a competitive edge, taking advanced visualization techniques and professional skills into their future projects.

p.strong: Articulation and progression: an investigation into the transition of engineering student from applied to more theoretical programme

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Continuing Engineering Education and Lifelong learning
Author's preference: Oral
Marisa Llorens1, Susan O'Shaughnessy1, Domhnall Sheridan1, Michael Carr1, Sheryl Sorby2 ,1, Brian Bowe1 1Dublin Institute of Technology, Dublin, Ireland, 2Ohio State University, Ohio, USA

The term articulation' in higher education refers to student' transition from short cycle applied programme to longer cycle theoretical programme. In many countries (e.g. Scotland, USA) this transition involves transferring from one institution to another (i.e. from college to university). In the Dublin Institute of Technology (DIT), however, this articulation takes place within the institution itself, so that student who successfully complete a 3-year engineering technology programme, known as an Ordinary degree, may apply to progress to the third year of a 4-year Honours degree in engineering, thus earning the Honours degree in five years instead of four. A significant number of the student who receive the Honours degree each year begin their studies in the Ordinary degree programme but the transition between the two programme, and the corresponding shift between applied and theoretical work, especially in mathematics, is not always easy to achieve. While most retention studies at the institution have focused on student making the transition from secondary to higher education in their first year, very little work has been done in examining retention trends for the student who progress from Ordinary to Honours programme. This paper will examine data and student experiences from the past several years to determine factors contributing to retention and eventual graduation for the student who attempt to complete the Honours programme but who started out in the Ordinary programme. Parallels will be drawn to international studies on student articulation, including the transitions involved in the Bologna process.

p.strong: Between humanism and competitiveness - towards an intercultural ethos for engineers

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: The Global Engineer
Author's preference: Oral
Christophe Morace1, Alison Gourv?Hayward2 1Ensta-Bretagne CRF 1410, Brest, France, 2Telecom-Bretagne, Brest, France

Ever-increasing globalisation in a complex, competitive and highly technical world has raised the question of ethics and social responsibility for many companies, organisations and individuals. The impact of such socio-technical issues on both engineering practices and education places the question of intercultural competences at the core of this debate. Definitions of intercultural competences deriving from research in the Humanities and Social Sciences tend to focus on an idealised view of humanity, whereas Cultural Intelligence research emphasizes cultural fact-finding and competence development for commercial ends.

Our research, based on findings from engineers in an intercultural professional context and student in two French Graduate Engineering Schools with an international campus, shows a need for both humanism and competitiveness. Observations of student learning in experiential, intercultural spaces revealed more humanistic attitudes and communication skills, while interviews with professional engineers in a competitive context showed that the greatest commercial success was invariably accompanied by strong humanistic competences.

In this paper, we will analyse the result of 10 years' practice and research on the transformation of international experience into intercultural competences and suggest a framework, combining humanism and competitiveness, which we call intercultural ethos for engineers. This concept includes cultural and intercultural competences, values and ethics but also self presentation, representation and negotiation of identity which can be observed and analysed in the discourse of practicing and student engineers. Our aim is to provide a contribution to the development of pertinent intercultural competences for the global engineering community.

p.strong: Using active learning methods to teach Applied Natural Sciences to first year student

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Active Learning
Author's preference: Oral
Sonia M. Gomez Puente, Richard Engeln Eindhoven University of Technology, Eindhoven, The Netherlands

Teaching Applied Natural Sciences (ANS) would not have ever been so challenging as this subject was not the common course for up to 1,800 first year student at the Eindhoven University of Technology (TU/e). Responding to the educational policy demands from the university educational management, innovation of education was to serve the new profile of the EngineerS of the Future' by emphasizing diversity in the study programs and by attracting student with different interests, among others. In addition, the curriculum transformation was aiming at increasing student' pass rate. Within this framework, the ANS course has been redesigned to meet curriculum requirements. The didactic underpinnings of the ANS course lie in the combination of active learning techniques, i.e. Peer Instruction method; in the use of ICT, i.e. electronic response devices; and in the integration of formative assessment through electronic platforms.

The ANS course aims at teaching basic concepts on mechanics, fluid dynamics, harmonic motion, and thermodynamics with the application of active learning approach, to involve actively student during weekly lectures and tutorials.

In this paper, we report on the result of student' perceptions regarding three consecutive academic years. result show that student became more enthusiastic about the interactive setup of the lectures while pass rates do not show a clear trend. We explore, therefore, how active learning in combination with other methods has supported student to learn physics concepts. For the purpose of this paper we focus on the result of only one group combining physics, chemistry, and mathematics student.

p.strong: Diagnostic tests for student bridging to the Master's programmeinEngineering Technology.

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Curriculum Development
Author's preference: Oral
Greet Langie, Carolien Van Soom KU Leuven, Leuven, Belgium

In Belgium one distinguishes two types of bachelor degrees: the professional and the academic bachelor. A professional bachelor degree does not grant automatic access to a master's programme, whereas an academic bachelor degree does.However professional bachelors are not excluded from a master's programme, they can start this study after finishing successfully a bridging programme (45-90 ECTS points).

The number of bridging student in the Faculty of Engineering Technology of KU Leuven is increasing systematically year after year with 7% on average. For the moment 900 student are bridging, whereas 3700 student are enrolled in the academic Bachelor of Science in Engineering Technology. So one out of five student who is trying to get the necessary degree to start a Master's programme in Engineering Technology, is a bridging student.

The success rate of these bridging programme is however very low. Since these bridging student have already a degree which is very valuable in industry, we would like to give these student a reliable idea of their changes to succeed in a bridging programme before they start these two extra years. In this project we implemented three diagnostic tests, developed for freshman who start the academic Bachelor of Science in Engineering technology (mathematics, academic language skills and scientific reasoning). We have investigated the validity of the tests for this population and we can conclude that only the mathematics test has moderate predictability.

p.strong: Safety knowledge for professional engineers and student:A global scheme of education.

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Continuing Engineering Education and Lifelong learning
Author's preference: Poster
Eva Giagloglou, Marko Djapan, Christos Tsiafis, Pavle Mijovic, Ivan Macuzic University of Kragujevac, Kragujevac, Serbia

The modern industry continuously adopts new technology and new occupational standards. These novelties bring the need of improved and up to date occupational safety knowledge and practice. In order to offer a complete scheme of education the university of Kragujevac installed three lines of balanced educational packages.

The first line regards academia, where there are established safety curricula in under and post graduate education as well as various doctorate safety-research programme. In parallel, there is a second line of education, revolted to professionals, under the framework of Lifelong learning. These programme are divided into modules for facilitating the stakeholders' choice. The third line is revolted to research, for providing solutions in main machinery and safety-related problems, in view of continuous and dynamic collaboration with industrial partners.

Occupational safety is a worldwide basic need, furthermore, legislative and social changes push into a more demanding strategy. These three lines of education are structured to cover the whole spectrum of safety education. The University of Kragujevac assumed the role to up to date the safety professionals, establish collaborations with industry, dynamically get involved into real industrial problems and finally prepare future professionals, able to affront coming challenges in safety issues. This paper presents strategic educational methods and provides qualitative and quantitative result, that may be used by other institutions wishing to implement educational packages of occupational safety. The result include rating of the presented Lifelong learning programme and percentages of hired student, after the completion of their internship in the industrial company.

p.strong: Investigating the perceptions of professional engineers that undergraduate engineering student hold?

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: The Attractiveness of Engineering
Author's preference: Oral
Jenna Tudor1, Helen Hooper1, Oana Bretcanu2 1Northumbria University, Newcastle upon Tyne, UK, 2Newcastle University, Newcastle upon Tyne, UK

There is an international deficit of scientists and engineers. For example, a 2012 report indicates that training at current rates will result in a 1,000,000 shortfall to meet workforce demands across the next decade just in the US. Such reports call for increased training but also highlight an imperative to develop better retention strategies, especially for women, who are starkly under-represent within many science and engineering fields.

In order to enhance induction/ transition support for first year student and develop better career/ post graduate study development support we investigated what student understood of the routine activities that professional scientists/ engineers engage with. student at 3 regional HEIs on a range of STEM programme at levels 4 and 6 were challenged to articulate their understanding, along with providing information about pre entry motivations for choice of subject/ university course, post graduate study/ career aspirations and parental/ carer occupation. student were also asked to complete a Draw a Scientist/ Engineer' task and the visual images drawn were analysed for gender and level of stereotype.
The data reveals a range of misconceptions, including gender biased stereotypes, variations within data from different HEI's and implications for practice which will be discussed.

p.strong: Degrading of PhD s through the introduction of doctoral schools

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Curriculum Development
Author's preference: Oral

In 2007 SEFI published a statement regarding the third cycle of the Bologna Process: the Doctorate in Engineering. The statement emphasised the importance of individual research work. A PhD in Engineering should reflect the individual s research competencies. Consequently, qualifying as a researcher with a PhD should be the result of an individual learning process rather than curriculum-based education.

As the third cycle of qualification in higher education is taking shape, many university in different countries established a doctoral school to organise the PhD process. More and more, the doctoral degree program takes the form of a formal curriculum. At least part of the PhD requirements is defined by participation in a course programme.

Traditionally, PhD theses are the result of university based research projects, or research work performed at research institutes. The task of the supervisor was mostly that of a referee judging when the PhD candidate was ready to defend the thesis, a process that could take up to ten years. Presently a supervisor is expected to coach the PhD student aiming for a degree within four, or even three years.

It will be difficult to prove actual degrading of the level of PhD thesis over the past decade. In fact many highly interesting and sophisticated studies are currently being published. However, the fact that people starting their PhD enrol in a three-year doctoral school programme restricts their expectations of developing into a fully independent researcher. The presentation aims to discuss the impact on the careers of young researchers.

p.strong: Who Has Heard About the HEAR? Evaluation of initial employer impact of the Higher Education Achievement Record

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Entrepreneurship of Employability
Author's preference: Oral
Jenna Tudor, Roger Penlington, Helen Hooper, Helen Manns Northumbria University, Newcastle upon Tyne, UK

The Higher Education Achievement Report (HEAR) arose as a recommendation from the final Burgess report Beyond the Honours Degree Classification' and was first implemented in 2012-2013, with wide spread roll out continuing across the UK HEI sector. The HEAR includes a range of University validated activities - with an underpinning focus on employability, therefore the main risk to the Department/ HEI if the HEAR is not effectively implemented is an impact on the employability of their student. There is currently little information available from employers regarding whether they are aware of the HEAR, what they think of HEARs, if they have seen them, or what they would like to see on a HEAR etc.

In order to evaluate the initial employer impact of the HEAR we developed a focussed online survey which was administered to over 150 STEM employers and post graduate course admissions tutors and targeted at individuals who participate in the graduate recruitment procedures for the company/organisation. Data was also collected from undergraduate Engineering student to demonstrate the level of student awareness of the HEAR. The session will focus on the data obtained from the Engineering employers and the student to inform future development of the HEAR, to encourage student to engage with relevant HEAR activities and to encourage staff to provide support/opportunities for student to engage with relevant HEAR activities.

p.strong: Exploiting the Thesis Research: Educating Engineering PhD student to Think and to Act Entrepreneurially

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Entrepreneurship of Employability
Author's preference: Oral
Aonghus McNabola, Paul Coughlan Trinity College Dublin, Dublin, Ireland

In preparing their thesis, doctoral researchers are challenged to address significant issues with the potential to contribute to knowledge. Increasingly, there is an expectation of relevance to society. For the doctoral researcher, the resulting thesis may form the basis for an innovative and entrepreneurial response to the issue. To realise this potential, doctoral education needs to enable collaboration with other disciplines and with practitioners, and encourage thinking and acting innovatively and entrepreneurially.

The Graduate Certificate in Innovation and Entrepreneurship is offered to all doctoral student, including Engineering, at Trinity College Dublin as part of a structured PhD Programme. The course locates entrepreneurship and creative thinking in the context of the thesis and challenges student to explore and exploit innovative opportunities for commercial and/or social benefit in the thesis. This course is transforming the doctoral education experience of student by establishing innovation alongside research and education as an integral element of their PhD. The output is a new breed of graduate, expert in their discipline, but confident in innovation and entrepreneurship.

This paper outlines a longitudinal case study of 6 Engineering PhD student who have engaged in this programme, and is based on student interviews and programme documentation. The integration with the Engineering curriculum is outlined, including, student progression and supervision. The paper reflects on the benefits in terms of graduate attributes and employability.

p.strong: Accreditation criteria as enablers

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Quality Assurance and Accreditation
Author's preference: Oral

In the UK, the standards of competence and commitment that must be demonstrated to achieve professional registration as an engineers or technician are established by the regulatory body, the Engineering Council. A key element is the required underpinning knowledge and understanding, which for professional engineers is usually delivered via a university degree programme designed to meet the Engineering Council's criteria.

This paper draws on the Engineering Council's recent five year review of the degree accreditation criteria. This involved collaboration across the profession, including employers, academics and professional organisations, thus providing an opportunity to ensure that engineering degrees continue to equip graduates for employment in the 21st century. This paper outlines: the review process; the thinking behind some of the revisions: the balance between avoiding whole-scale change to a standard that was broadly supported by stakeholders, whilst addressing matters that have come to the fore since the previous review (including ethics, security and risk management); and taking account of external drivers from the UK Government and others to enhance skills and graduate employability.

Particular attention is paid to two key revisions: the integration of what are commonly termed general learning outcomes' (which tend to underpin the employability or transferable skills that employers say theyrequire) to be within the specific engineering/technical learning outcomes; and the clearer presentation of the distinctiveness between the four types of UK engineering degree. Relevant and appropriate accreditation criteria are presented as enablers for university engineering departments wishing to develop or update their degree programme.

p.strong: The SUTD-MIT Global Leadership Programme: Attempting institutional transplantation through cross-cultural student leadership development

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: The Global Engineer
Author's preference: Oral
Dara Fisher1, Aikaterini Bagiati2, John Brisson2 1Harvard University, Cambridge, MA, USA, 2Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA, USA

Over the last decade, numerous higher education institutions have begun to engage in cross-border efforts and initiatives, especially in the discipline of engineering and technical education. While these efforts have great diversity in size and scope, the largest of these projects are those attempting complete institutional transplantation of the academic, student, and research culture of one institution to another. In 2010, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) began one such project in collaboration with the Singapore Ministry of Education to create the Singapore University of Technology and Design (SUTD). In planning for this project, the MIT-SUTD Collaboration staff identified three unique pathways towards institutional transplantation: faculty development, undergraduate curriculum design, and initiatives related to student life.

In the realm of student leadership, MIT staff members sought to transfuse the innovative, entrepreneurial, bottom-up and free-spirited culture of the MIT undergraduate community to the student body of SUTD. To address this goal, in 2013 the Collaboration staff developed and executed the SUTD-MIT Global Leadership Programme (GLP), a ten-week summer exchange in Cambridge, Massachusetts, for 28 members of the inaugural SUTD student cohort. Through GLP, SUTD student actively engaged with the MIT community, while simultaneously receiving training in teamwork, design, entrepreneurship, education, and technical communication, all delivered through the leadership lens and with particular emphasis on the leadership component. This paper presents the design, development, and execution of the inaugural GLP program, as well as an explanation of this program as a specific vehicle for MIT s institutional transplantation effort in the SUTD project.

p.strong: Design of an MSc Degree course in Aerospace Structures and Materials

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Curriculum Development
Author's preference: Oral

p.em: Delft University of Technology, Delft, The Netherlands

body.p: With the implementation of the Bologna Agreement at Delft University of Technology the traditional 5-year Master of Science in Aerospace Engineering degree was split in 3- year BSc degree followed by a 2-year MSc degree. Although initially the actual underlying curriculum was left unchanged the department of Aerospace Structures and Materials decided to redesign their MSc programme to meet the needs of the modern student and facilitate the thought behind the Bologna agreement of student mobility throughout Europe and beyond. The programme will also incorporate online learning and will go live in September 2014.

This paper will detail the curriculum design of the new MSc programme, the didactical background on which it is based and share experiences from the lecturers involved in the design process. The paper will be of interest to anyone who is rethinking the design of their existing degree courses.

p.strong: Spatial Skills as a Key to Success in Engineering

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Issues of Gender and Diversity
Author's preference: Oral
Sheryl Sorby, Edmund Nevin, Avril Behan, Eileen Mageean, Sarah Sheridan Dublin Institute of Technology, Dublin, Ireland

Through numerous research studies conducted over the past fifty years, the importance of well-developed 3-D spatial skills for success in engineering and other STEM fields has been widely demonstrated. Research conducted in the U.S. and elsewhere, has demonstrated the high level of spatial skills found in student of engineering and architecture; however, not all of our first-year student have strong spatial skills when they start their post-secondary studies. Poor spatial skills put these student at a distinct disadvantage when completing introductory courses in CAD, descriptive geometry, and graphic communications requirements in many STEM programs. In turn, this often leads to poor grades and dropping out of engineering or architecture as a result. In this study, the spatial skills of first-year student in several engineering and technology programs were assessed through use of standardized instruments. The spatial skills of architecture and computer science student were also assessed. End-of-semester grades for the student in several key courses were also obtained to determine if there is a correlation between spatial skill level and student performance. This paper outlines the result obtained from this study and draws conclusions regarding the importance of spatial skills for success in introductory STEM courses. result obtained through this testing will be compared across disciplines and programs and will be compared to similar data obtained from testing engineering student in the U.S.

p.strong: International Student Teams Solving Real Problems for Industry in Senior Capstone Projects

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: The Global Engineer
Author's preference: Either

p.em: Purdue University, West Lafayette, IN, USA

body.p: Most undergraduate student do not have the opportunity to travel abroad and experience and develop communication skills with others cultures. However in this global world, today's engineers is likely to have to work in global international teams with colleagues from other nationalities. The challenge for many engineering curricula is how to include, in a realistic way, this global dimension.

In the Purdue University engineering technology program an international capstone project is being created and introduced in the coming year. This international capstone project builds on the existing, industry sponsored, multi-disciplinary capstone team project that is required of all student. In the international project, half of the team members are student from a non-US university. The full team works on a project proposed by companies with a global footprint in both the U.S. and in proximity to the foreign institution. Most of the global project is carried out using the full range of electronic communication tools such as email, skype, and blogs. In addition two exchange trips are made with team members travelling to their opposite foreign location. Ideally the first trip occurs near the initiation of the project for planning, organizing and conceptualization. One of the challenges is the synchronization of the two curricula and the academic schedules of the two institutions.
This program is just being launched and this paper will be a progress report for the two first projects being undertaken this fall to increase the global awareness of our student.

p.strong: Understanding social learning behaviours of xMOOC completers

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Technology in Learning
Author's preference: Oral
Sasha Skrypnyk2, Thieme Hennis1, Pieter de Vries1 1Delft University of Technology, Delft, The Netherlands, 2University of South Australia, Adelaide, Australia

In general MOOCs differ from traditional university online courses in two ways: Open access, anyone can participate for free, and Scalability, courses are designed for a large number of participants. In that sense MOOCs are multicultural learning environments that need a sensitive approach in course design and facilitation to deal with the diversity of its student population to enhance participation and completion. Most research focuses on the individual although the opportunities for collaboration are numerous and we know that interaction has a positive influence on learning achievements, but how can this be supported in MOOCs to promote effective learning? Some learners have greater needs collaborating, while others may experience no such needs. Understanding these preferences through learners behaviours is critical. Identifying what learners are prone to explore the potential of collaboration, and which are not, has implications for pedagogical choices to support diverse learners.

This paper discusses social learning behaviour of participants in two xMOOCs from the Delft University of Technology (TUD) on the edX platform (Solar Energy and Water Treatment, Fall 2013). The paper will supply an overview of the research findings, describe the type of learners who were socially active and completed the MOOCs and the challenge of making MOOC facilitation and delivery more culturally sensitive. Our research suggest that social interaction with other learners is beneficial for student performance, but that forum strategies and platform affordances create unequal opportunities for participation, as MOOC learners are diverse and their needs differ, in the same way as their backgrounds.

p.strong: To Stay or Leave? A Plan for Using Phenomenology to ExploreGender and the Role of Experiential Learning in Engineering

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Education al Research Methods
Author's preference: Oral
Shannon Chance1 ,2, Brian Bowe2 1Hampton University, Hampton, VA, USA, 2Dublin Institute of Technology, Dublin, Ireland

Today, there is a gap in understanding of why women chose engineering and how they experience collaborative Problem-Based Learning (PBL). Phenomenology provides an ideal framework for studying such a topic.

This paper presentation discusses the design of a project funded as part of a Marie Curie International Incoming Fellows (IIF) grant to the Dublin Institute of Technology. At the core of the IIF project is a Phenomenological Study of How Women Experience Engineering Education: Understanding How PBL Influences Their Decisions to Join or Leave Engineering. Participants in the study are women in Ireland, Portugal, and Poland from four different segments of the engineering pipeline (high school, college, early career, and late career/CEOs). The sample of 24 includes women who have experienced PBL and others who have not.

The overall project addresses leaks in Europe's STEM pipeline that lead to shortfall and lack of diversity among European engineers. The EU faces an alarming deficit of engineers. In 2009, Belgium had 2500 unfilled engineering positions. In 2011, Germany needed 76,400 more people with engineering skills and 114,000 people with STEM skills. To address this and diversify perspectives, the EU must attract and retain more women in STEM. Prior research suggests that PBL increases student engagement and many help address reasons women avoid STEM subjects.
The intent of the SEFI presentation is to promote use of phenomenology in research on engineering education and to help perfect the design of the study through group discussion and critique.

p.strong: An aligned 'design approach' for the engineering curriculum

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Curriculum Development
Author's preference: Oral
Margriet de Jong, Elsje Londers, Inge Van Hemelrijck, Ludo Froyen KU Leuven, Leuven, Belgium

student at the Faculty of Engineering Science at KU Leuven develop their engineering design skills in several integrating team assignments 'Problem Solving and Design' (PandD) throughout the curriculum. These assignments gradually increase in complexity and student are increasingly expected to work independently.
result from a student survey show that student are positive about the PandD concept in general. Yet, student indicate that they receive little or no feedback on their performance in 'design'.

We aim to improve the assessment of and feedback on design skills by introducing a design approach model, tailored to our educational needs. This model serves as an outline for an aligned design curriculum pathway for a gradual development of student's competence in engineering design.

The design approach model is a schematic representation of the steps in the engineering design process and includes additional professional skills, such as teamwork, reporting and project management. Already in the first semester assignment the basic model is presented to the student, but we focus on only a few aspects, like teamwork. Subsequent assignments focus on other aspects, e.g. methods for evaluating ideas. At the start of each assignment the model is presented to the student, with an overview of what they learned already and what the focus of the new assignment will be. This will give student insight in how they gradually build up their competence in engineering design. An online system is introduced to guide the student in their self-assessment of the design competencies and to enhance providing structured feedback.

p.strong: Analysis of Analytics - Videoclip Watching activities in Introductory Physics

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Physics in EE
Author's preference: Oral
Juho Tiili, Sami Suhonen Tampere University of Applied Sciences, Tampere, Finland

The new studying method, "Combining good practices" , presented in SEFI2013, has been implemented in introductory physics teaching in Tampere UAS. In order to use lectures for active engagement of student and for continuous assessment, the routine-like tasks are pushed in to e-learning environment. Video-solutions, presented via YouTube, for exercise problems present key role in web content. student' studying habits concerning video material is analyzed using data gathered from student, Google analytics and e-learning log files. The data is gathered from the introductory engineering mechanics course. The interesting questions are: 1. How does the video watching activities vary according to the course timeline? 2. How much the videos are watched? 3. How does student' final grade correspond to video watching activities? 4. How do the student use the videos as learning tools? The result of the study show that nearly all of the student have used video material during the course and nearly all of them find it helpful concerning their course performance. It is obvious that activities concerning the video material is concentrated close to the week exams and the final exam. First glance of the statistics show that some of the videos are much more popular than the others. For example the ratio of views/student of the videos can vary from 0,30 to 1,1 within the mechanics course, based on the e-learning environment logs. Based on the log files, almost all student watch the videos, but a slight majority is student with lower final grades.

p.strong: Combining good practices in fully online learning environment introductory physics course

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Active Learning
Author's preference: Oral
Sami Suhonen, Juho Tiili Tampere University of Applied Sciences, Tampere, Finland

Based on a selection of good educational practices reported in the literature, a new method to study introductory engineering physics at Tampere UAS was introduced in SEFI 2013 conference. The method relies on: 1. Active engagement 2. Peer instruction 3. Interactive lecture demonstrations 4. Pre-lecture assignments, 5. Small scale measurement tasks 6. Video-content 7. Continuous assessment. The aim is to implement above mentioned practices in e-learning environment successfully. The challenges are: How to achieve interactivities while presenting demonstrations on video? How to carry out measurements individually at home, but still work on the assignment as a team? And all this with only the equipment a normal student has easily available. To achieve some interactivities of the demonstrations they are presented in several video episodes, so that the first part only presents the case in question. The student are then asked to record their individual and group discussion based predictions. Only after this the demonstration continues to next episodes and the student can analyze and reflect their conceptions and misconceptions about the phenomenon. The measurement assignments are divided to smaller tasks. After carrying out individual measurements, the result are shared among the student team. The final result of a measurement assignment is then based on the result of all individual tasks. Assessment will be based both on the individual parts as well as the final result. To keep track on the student' working, the teams are asked to provide a log of their discussions and chat.

p.strong: Industrial adjunct professors as a potential resource for developing engineering curricula - apilot study

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Industry involvement in EE
Author's preference: Oral
Per Fagrell1 ,2, Lars Geschwind1, Anders J??sten1 ,3 1KTH, Stockholm, Sweden, 2Teknikf??agen, Stockholm, Sweden, 3KK-stiftelsen, Stockholm, Sweden

During the last years many university seem to have recognised mobility of personnel as a way to increase knowledge transfer between academia and the surrounding society. Mobility in terms of adjunct faculty from industry is often used by higher education institutions (HEIs) as a means to strengthen the research and the research education. More seldom are adjunct faculty members used in the development of the curricula of bachelor and master level educations, even if companies collaborating with university often say that one of the top reasons to collaborate is the connection with the education and with the competence of the future.

This paper presents the findings from a pilot study with the aim to investigate if adjunct professors can be used as a strategic resource when it comes to develop engineering curricula. The paper also investigates their balance of work and their preferences and possible intentions to change the balance to more education, i.e. development of engineering curricula, at bachelor and master level. Data from three interviews have been used in the pilot study with the main purpose to form a model for the analysis of ca 30 interviews made during winter and spring 2014 at two university in Sweden. The preliminary result show that both industry and adjunct professors have an interest in education at bachelor and master levels. The bottleneck is, as always, lack of time as the adjunct professors normally only spend one day a week at the university.

p.strong: From a first cycle PBL environment to a more traditional master s programme: student impressions

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Education al Research Methods
Author's preference: Oral

p.em: 1Escola Superior de Tecnologia e Gest?de ueda, Universidade de Aveiro, Aveiro, Portugal, 2Centro de Investiga? em Did?ica e Forma? de Formadores, Universidade de Aveiro, Aveiro, Portugal

body.p: Technology programme at ueda s Polytechnic School (ESTGA), University of Aveiro (UA), have been organised in a PBL environment since 2001. On reflection, it is possible to state that an institutional cultural change has effectively taken place.

Although ESTGA is one of UA s departments, it is located in an industrialized region, 25km away from Aveiro. Therefore, ESTGA developed its own dynamics: its own campus; its polytechnic nature, and an established PBL environment.

After Bologna, UA created continuity master programme , allowing 1st cycle graduates to enrol in pre-defined 2nd cycle programme without other selection processes. For ESTGA s Electrical Engineering programme, the continuity is the Master in Industrial Automation Engineering (MIAE), offered by the Electronics Engineering and the Mechanical Engineering departments, at UA s main campus. student taking this path face a transition from ESTGA s PBL environment to a more traditional setting.

This investigation aims to understand the difficulties felt by student in the transition process, and the impact of their PBL background in a more traditional environment. Five out of seventeen student that, over the past years, enrolled the MIASE were interviewed. The interviews were qualitatively analysed.

result show that student struggle with teacher/student relationships and class organisation in the new environment. student also have initial difficulties with the more formal approach to Mathematics, although they all report that those difficulties fade rapidly. However, student feel better prepared for the practical activities in the master s programme than colleagues with different backgrounds, and proudly report that they feel better equipped to solve problems autonomously.

p.strong: Gender and diversity as integral part of engineering education - Review of SEFI conference papers and articles of the European Journal of Engineering Education between 2005 and 2011 for future conclusions

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Issues of Gender and Diversity
Author's preference: Oral
Susanne Ihsen, Katharina Scheibl Technische Universit?M??en, M??en, Germany

Subject of the review are 60 papers and project descriptions that were presented at the SEFI Conferences between 2005 and 2011 and 33 articles that were published in the European Journal of Engineering Education (EJEE) within the same time period, including three special issues Summarizing the total number of 60 papers and 33 articles the topics that are covered can be clustered into four different categories: (1) Gender and diversity relevance in engineering education, (2) cultural change in engineering education and professional practice, (3) women career and leadership, and finally (4) models of work-life-balance. With a total of 54 papers and articles most contributions fall under the first category. The research orientation varies between project descriptions and empirical research approach. The great majority (60) can be categorized under the dimension Gender Equality on all Levels of Qualification. The papers were published by 225 Authors. While the majority of 152 authors were female, there was also a significant number of 73 male contributors. The authors come from as much as 30 different countries, the majority is originated in European countries. The paper shows the status of gender and diversity in engineering and will link this to the state of the art of gender and diversity studies. The conclusions discuss further perspectives of the topic in engineering education.

p.strong: Like Going to Mars , Research Exchange Experience sat Tokyo Institute of Technology

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: The Global Engineer
Author's preference: Either
Jeffrey S. Cross, Kikuo Kishimoto, Hidetoshi Sekiguchi, Masahiro Susa Tokyo Institute of Technology, Meguro-ku, Tokyo, Japan

Since 2005, Tokyo Institute of Technology's (Tokyo Tech) Graduate School of Engineering has created and utilized bilateral summer student research exchanges with premier engineering university world-wide to promote global engineering skills development. Two different research exchange programs were created initially: Summer Exchange Research Program (SERP) with European and American university and then the Asia Oceania Top University League on Engineering (AOTULE) for exchanges with Asian and Oceania university. These formed the basis for a new university-wide program called Tokyo Tech International Research Opportunities Program (TiROP) with many of the same partners. Although these programs require significant financial and human resources to operate, a number of positive attributes have been observed as a result,
- greater student diversity on Tokyo Tech's campuses and opportunities for overseas and local student to interact
- student' gain cross-cultural competency, overseas project leadership experience and show foreign language ability improvement
- increase in univ./school-level exchange agreements and creation of new programs with partners
- participating student show improved self-confidence and maturity after the exchange is completed

In other words, overseas research exchanges are well suited for training future global engineers and scientists to work in a non-native language speaking world. In fact, some of the European exchange student have described their living and research experience at Tokyo Tech,"like going to Mars", since it was beyond their imagination. In this presentation, best practices will be discussed on what are the essential elements to maintain sustainable exchanges, program challenges and future prospects.

p.strong: Learn different, learn somewhere else. Does changing the environment impact student's leaning?

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Active Learning
Author's preference: Oral
Rapha?Bary1, Michael Rees2, Julie Galland1 1ERPI - University of Lorraine, Nancy, France, 2ENSGSI - University of Lorraine, Nancy, France

"It's not what you know that counts anymore. It's what you can learn." As mentioned by Don Tapscott, the Canadian business strategist, a major issue is to prepare student for an ever-changing future where learning will be fundamental. Therefore, a French engineering school uses self-directed language learning framework to improve both student' proficiency in foreign languages and their capacity to learn autonomously.

During an eight-hour course the issues and modalities of self-directed learning are presented. But how a traditional class can clarify what self-directed learning is? What can raise student' awareness of the necessity to learn differently?

Over the time, the course structure and contents has been improved. Yet, we have noticed that student' attention decrease during these long hours in the same classroom even if knowledge transmission and more active phases alternate. As studies suggest that spaces and environments influence teachers' pedagogical practices and student' learning efficiency, we wondered if teaching each sequence in a place, symbolically linked with the content we want to transmit, could impact positively our teaching.

Consequently, we devised an experiment. Each course sequence takes place in a particular place and, afterwards, student complete a questionnaire in order to evaluate: is changing places meaningful for them? Does it affect their comprehension of what self-directed involves?...

This paper will discuss the role of the teaching environment and present our self-directed learning framework as well as the course. The result of the questionnaire are presented to testify that student feedbacks validate the experiment and also suggest improvements.

p.strong: Team-based learning in Mathematics courses

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Maths in EE
Author's preference: Oral
Lamjed Bettaieb1, Kaouthar Louati1, Lobna Derbel2 1ESPRIT: Higher institute of ingineering of technology, EL Ghazela, Tunisia, 2ISI: High institute of computer sciences, Ariana, Tunisia

Mathematics are essential for the training of an effective engineer, it helps develop skills such as reasoning, rigorousness and responsiveness. On the other hand, its abstractness can somehow demotivate student who deem Mathematics useless in their upcoming professional life. Consequently, adopting a new methodology, which is simple, motivating and interesting has been a significant challenge these past two years at ESPRIT. Besides, while reviewing the form, the content and the objectives of our courses, we have encountered numerous difficulties to apply the active learning pedagogy in basic mathematics courses. In fact, once the engineering speciality subject is selected, a set of interdisciplinary projects meeting corporate expectations are developed using precise mathematical tools. The learners will be extra-motivated because they have to solve factual problems. Our new experience is to combine effective practice and teamwork on so many levels. Team-based learning approach produced spectacular result in terms of learning performance, motivation levels, attendance records as well as engineering skills.

This paper is to depict our new experience. We relied on statistical and comparative studies between classes, changes in attendance records and examination result. We have also utilized testimonials of student who have tested this new approach.

p.strong: Investigating First-Year Engineering student' Understandings of Computer Simulations and Interactivities

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Technology in Learning
Author's preference: Oral
Kelsey Rodgers, Heidi Diefes-Dux, Krishna Madhavan Purdue University, West Lafayette, Indiana, USA

Introduction: The purpose of this paper is to investigate student' understandings of interactivities, models, and simulations to inform curriculum development. We explore how student assess the level of interactivities of graphical user interfaces (GUIs) that were developed by their peers as part of a nanotechnology simulation design project. Further, we study how student characterize the presence of mathematical models and simulations.

Context: In Spring 2014, a cohort of 346 first-year engineering student enrolled at a U.S. Midwestern university were required to develop interactive MATLAB-based GUIs focused on demonstrating foundational nanotechnology concepts through simulations.

Methodology: student were asked to determine the level of interactivities and presence of models and simulations in prior student' GUI design projects. student assessed interactivities with a 5-point rubric item. student were also given yes or no questions to assess the presence of a model or simulation. Further, student were asked to explain their ratings. The three GUI projects under review by the student had the following characteristics. (A) Basic Level of Interaction (e.g. clicking to pull up more information, selecting quiz answers), (B) Animation of a Simulation - user can only play the simulation with default input variables, and (C) Simulation - user can change input variables. A mixed-method approach was taken to study student' responses.
In the full paper, based on identified patterns across the student responses, we discuss implications for future research and curriculum development focusing on simulation design and use.

p.strong: Completing the SIP activities framework - what through placement activities should they, and do they, do?

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Industry involvement in EE
Author's preference: Oral
Judith Shawcross, Tom Ridgman University of Cambridge, Cambridge, UK

This paper continues work, reported at SEFI 2013, to identify student activities in short industrial placements (SIPs) undertaken during their post graduate degree. The programme studied contains a series of four SIPs where groups of two student work on real issues for the host companies.

Exploratory research on preparing graduates for SIPs found a lack of clear and consistent description of the activities. Last year, an activities framework was developed describing a SIP in terms of twelve process activities groups with sixty four associated key activities and five through placement activities groups.

This year the aim was to determine the key activities for the five through project activities groups of; project management, managing the relationship with the client, working with others, managing self and working with and managing information, to complete the framework. A review of literature enabled each group to be described in the context of a SIP and broken down into key activities. Following each project, student recorded what they considered to be the most important activities. After sorting and clustering the data, followed by a comparison with the literature, it was possible to determine the key activities.
The full result are still being processed but preliminary findings indicate that key activities have been identified for SIP through project activities.

Thus the framework is now complete and this will enable us to describe these complex industrial placements consistently to student, companies and tutors in terms of activities as well as support further research on skill development.

strong.i: PROJECT BASED LEARNING: A CASE STUDY WITH

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Active Learning
Author's preference: Oral
Carolaine Santos, Mayara Bortoti, Marco Pereira USP - School of Engineering of Lorena, Lorena, S?Paulo State, Brazil

p.i: The various transformations arising from technological, scientific and social advances, among others, have led people to new attitudes and behaviors. The adaptation of individuals, faced with these changes, affects the education. In line with this, university have been investing in new methods of learning in order to prepare the student for their future profession better, because the labor market searches for differentiated professionals who have, besides solid technical training, well-developed soft skills. This paper assesses the development of Industrial Engineering freshmen from the School of Engineering of Lorena, University of S?Paulo, in their first term, making use of Project-Based Learning. student have joined in groups and each group had a tutor. A case study was conducted and the main research tools used were two questionnaires answered by the student, one at midterm and the other at the end, as well as an interview with each of the tutors. In addition, have been also analyzed the material produced by the student throughout the term: reports, minutes of meetings and blogs. It was found that Project-Based Learning: (i) has accelerated the development of soft skills of student, among which, teamwork, project management and communication stand out and (ii) has contributed to the improvement of personal and professional development of student more rapidly. An important indirect result was the approval of one of the projects, by funding source, which led the project to be entirely implemented.

p.strong: Innovative on Demand International Engineering Programs

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: The Global Engineer
Author's preference: Oral

Claudio Brito1, Melany Ciampi2, Rosa Vasconcelos3, Luis Amaral4, Victor Barros1 1Science and Education Research Council - COPEC, S?Paulo, Brazil, 2Safety, Health and Environment Research Organization - SHERO, S?Paulo, Brazil, 3Pedagogical Council of the School of Engineering - University of Minho, Guimar?, Portugal, 4Computer Graphics Center - CCG, Guimar?, Portugal

The world of today is a challenging environment in all aspects including educational. It is a fact that education is important once it provides men the tools that are necessary to act in a world of high technology and real time information availability. It is a scenario that was almost impossible to foresee not along ago. In times of high-speed communication and real time information delivery, information technology in its entire spectrum has become very important for companies and professionals. And it is the science that now provides the environment for new technology application in educational community including. Following these new trends of high education the COPEC International Institute of Education is offering courses in engineering that are customized not only for enterprises but also for groups of professionals or in academia interested in acquiring special knowledge with a valid certification. The programs are dimensioned in according to the knowledge and practice that are necessary for the group of professional engineers or in academia. They make the requirements and the program is designed to fit their needs. They are partially on class and some content on line as long as it comprises the amount of hours that are necessary to accomplish the program focusing in the main goal to have a certified course of specialists in certain field of expertise. The proposed program is an investment that guarantees return by the strategic vision for a successful performance, the higher management capacity and the growth of intellectual capital.

p.strong: Focusing the Future of Engineering Education

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Continuing Engineering Education and Lifelong learning
Author's preference: Oral

Melany Ciampi1, Claudio Brito2, Rosa Vasconcelos3, Luis Amaral4, Victor Barros2 1Safety, Health and Environment Research Organization - SHERO, S?Paulo, Brazil, 2Science and Education Research Council - COPEC, S?Paulo, Brazil, 3Pedagogical Council of the School of Engineering - University of Minho, Guimar?, Portugal, 4Computer Graphics Center - CCG, Guimar?, Portugal

The world that student are facing has some characteristics that have consequences for the formation of engineers. One of them it the constant changes in the way people develop the work. This aspect is enhanced by the quick and strong technology development. student today require more advice than properly information acquisition once information is now available any time any place and in a huge amount and they are connected all time. The definitions of teacher and student are changing and Education is moving out of episodic experiences at traditional institutions like classrooms and schools into learning flows that course through our daily lives. So utilizing emerging technology to provide expanded learning opportunities is critical to the success of future generations. Teachers have to be prepared to motivate and entice the student about getting knowledge pertinent for their formation as engineers. The use of new technology in classroom is also an important requirement for teachers in High Education principally in Engineering, it is part of teaching environment now. It is clear that it is life long learning environment not only for future engineers but also for the teachers. This paper describes the "International Engineering Educator" Program developed by the engineering education research team of COPEC Science and Education Research Council. It is offered by the International Institute of Education of COPEC an organization that certifies in according to the Ministry of education of the Country in according to the National Law of High Education, with an international certification.

p.strong: Future teaching of mathematics for engineers

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Maths in EE
Author's preference: Oral

p.em: Norwegian University of Science and Technology, Trondheim, Norway

body.p: In many countries an increased awareness of the quality of learning and teaching mathematics for engineers can be observed, and many projects are being launched aiming at improved learning outcome for student. This paper will report on a project at the Norwegian University of Science and Technology, where basic mathematics is being taught to around 1500 engineering student in each cohort. The project is in its initial phase, building on a pilot project from 2013.

The overarching aim of this project is that the student should develop a deep understanding for mathematical concepts and processes, making them better equipped to use mathematics in applications. To reach this aim it is recognised that student own activities and involvement is crucial, and that an increased communication between student and teachers is essential. An important part of the project is using digital technology where this is advantageous in order to free teacher resources for use in better ways, i.e. to enhance contact with student. Digital technology is also important to offer diverse learning resources, acknowledging that student work and learn in different ways.

From the pilot project there exist empirical data from interviews of a small number of student and answers to a survey that was administered to the whole cohort. The paper will report on the main elements of the project as well as findings from the pilot study. These data indicate that student are rather conservative in their choices. Traditional elements like textbook and lectures are still in very high regard.

p.strong: Engineering creativity education in Russian university

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Engineering Design
Author's preference: Either
Irina Pertova, Viktoriya Zaripova Astrakhan Engineering Institute of Civil Construction, Astrakhan, Russia

During the TEMPUS TUNING-RUSSIA project (2010-2013) 18 Russian university together with European partners interviewed 358 employers, 1788 graduates, 187 professors in order to elaborate and estimate the list of generic competences in nine different subject areas, including ICT. The questionnaires rated the importance of generic and professional competences for professional work, and level of university performance in teaching of each competence.

It revealed the strengths and weaknesses of the educational program. Graduates estimated competences Ability for abstract thinking, analysis and synthesis? Ability to team-work? Knowledge and understanding of the subject area and profession?as highly important, but having insufficient level of development in Russian university.

A project-oriented course Methods of Creativity in Engineering?was elaborated to correct this situation. It provides student with a practical introduction to the methods of engineering creativity (brainstorming, Delphi method, morphological analysis and synthesis, Theory of Inventive Problem Solving - TRIZ, etc.). Its second part is devoted to the new group of software products designed to support innovation processes in enterprises - computer Aided Innovation?(CAI).
The article discussed in details the structure of the course, result of the course mini-projects, and the core of CAI, developed on the basis of energy-information method of conceptual design [1].
student peer review demonstrates that the competences have a good enough level of implementation in the course program.

[1] M.Zaripov, I.Petrova, V.Zaripova Use of integrated base of knowledge on physical effects during training the engineers., Proceedings of the 30th SEFI Conference, Firenze 8-11 September 2002, p.102

p.strong: Inter-department Project Based Learning for Doctor's Course student

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Curriculum Development
Author's preference: Oral
Yasuyuki Yokono, Shigehiko Kaneko, Shigeo Maruyama, Mamoru Mitsuishi The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan

Today s doctoral education must prepare student to be able to work in a broader spectrum and apply one s skills to a multidisciplinary setting while maintaining a high level of expertise. In order to solving some of world's complex problems, innovative doctors cultivated with literacy (language, information literacy, technological literacy, legal knowledge, and ethics) and competency (creativity, problem identification and solution, planning and execution, self-management, teamwork, leadership, a sense of responsibility and duty) are highly desired. To obtain these abilities, it is not enough to take a university lecture or to conduct an experiment in a laboratory.

This paper outlines the development of inter-department Project Based Learning for doctor's course student. In this course, student leaders and members deal industrial world-based themes and make solutions under the guidance of an industrial project manager and additional help from faculty facilitators. The teams are consisted by different specialization and nationality student. The aim of the Project Based Learning is to provide tough training in problem solving based on needs and integrated cooperation with other fields, to become aware of the importance of trans-disciplinary exchange, to experience team management, and to give tough training in communicating result. Instead of student from the same field working toward a specific goal in the fastest possible time, the PBL is characterized by student from different departments working together on an interdisciplinary problem.

p.strong: Challenges of teaching and learning in first-year engineering studies - teachers' observations

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Education al Research Methods
Author's preference: Oral

Pirjo Pietik?en1, P?i Kinnunen2, Erkki Pesonen3 1Aalto University, School of Chemical Technology, Espoo, Finland, 2Aalto University, School of Science, Espoo, Finland, 3University of Eastern Finland, School of Computing, Joensuu, Finland

In this paper we discuss the observations of our on-going study on engineering teachers' experiences of challenges that teaching first-year student pose to teachers. We have concentrated on subject independent challenges in order to be able to underline questions relevant to a larger audience of first year teachers. In many studies in engineering education field student' point of view is emphasized and teachers' or teaching organizations' viewpoint is not in a focus. Thus, this paper contributes to building a holistic picture of teaching and learning processes at the higher education level by providing less documented point of view.

As a data we have altogether 15 teacher interviews from two university. Our interviewees included computer science teachers and chemical engineering teachers. Qualitative content analysis revealed several challenges teachers face, such as, teaching problems solving skills, enhancing motivation, finding out the student' knowledge level and understanding the ways student are thinking, and finally also resources that university provides for teaching. The result showed surprisingly similar kinds of challenges regardless of the university or field. The result provide material for discussion on pedagogical leadership as well as relevant information for demands and planning of pedagogical training.

p.strong: Global Engineering Skills - Practice and Perspective of Joint Educational programme in Engineering between a German and Malaysian university -

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: The Global Engineer
Author's preference: Oral
Axel Hunger1, Marzuki Mustafa2, Stefan Werner1 1University of Duisburg-Essen, Duisburg, Germany, 2Universiti Kebangsaan Malaysia, Bangi, Malaysia

Universiti Kebangsaan Malaysia (UKM, The National University of Malaysia) and University Duisburg-Essen (UDE) in Germany co-operate since 2000. Major result are double degree (Bachelor and PhD) and exchange programme (all levels). Both partners collaborate on eye level', agree on outcomes of degree courses and carefully check for equivalences in their curricula. Student mobility shows more than 100 persons in each direction. In 2011, UKM received the "Best Jury Award for Higher Education Institute for Providing Global Student Exposure" from World Education Summit, New Delhi, India; collaboration with UDE was highlight for merit of the award.

Partnership has been institutionalised by the UKM-Mercator Office, an outpost of UDE at UKM, established in 2002, and UKM International Office at UDE, established in 2010, acting as bridge head at the partner.

Recently, partners are fine-tuning their programme to prepare graduates for the global labour market, beyond pure technical contents, which is standardised around the world. Credits are offered for non-technical courses with intensive experience regarding foreign culture and behaviour as key for global engineering competence.

Partners shared many best practices and learned the work culture which is crucial to sustain long term collaboration. Next step will be to integrate further partners in Southeast Asia, creating a network including south-south mobility to share work load and give the network more strength and visibility. In this context, curricula will be enhanced by new courses integrating technical subjects and cultural experience (e.g. by capstone projects) to give good grounds for the "Global Engineering Skills" offered.

p.strong: Authors' perceptions of peer review of conference papers and how theycharacterise a good' one

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Education al Research Methods
Author's preference: Oral
Anne Gardner, Keith Willey University of Technology, Sydney, Sydney, Australia

Peer review has been the focus of study at conferences of the Australasian Association for Engineering Education (AAEE) since 2010. The preliminary studies were extended to explore AAEE authors' perspective/s of the potential of peer review to support their development as researchers. An important objective of this research is to help members of the AAEE community to better understand themselves and their peers as they transition to the different perspectives and research methods involved in educational research compared to most engineering research.
This paper describes a study which was undertaken with active members of the AAEE community to explore the following questions:

ul.li: What is the perceived purpose of peer review?
What does the community mean by quality in the context of a conference paper?
What are the characteristics of a quality review on a conference paper?

body.p: Participants came from a range of types of university and with various levels of educational research experience. A thematic analysis of interview transcripts showed that providing feedback to authors in reviews was equally as important to them as the role of quality assurance of the conference papers. We were able to establish for these AAEE authors the characteristics of both a quality conference paper and a quality review. The result of this study are first steps in improving our shared understandings of what constitutes quality research in engineering education and how we might better convey that in offering constructive advice to authors when writing a review of a conference paper.

p.strong: Mapping the landscape of engineering education research: an Australian perspective

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Education al Research Methods
Author's preference: Oral
Anne Gardner, Keith Willey University of Technology, Sydney, Sydney, Australia

Engineering education research is still consolidating as a recognised research area in Australian university. This paper reports using a landscape model to demonstrate engineering education as a knowledge domain that includes a variety of areas of endeavour. This landscape was motivated by questions about how we define our research domain including the perceived differences between practice, scholarship and research and how the engineering education community can better understand and support itself to collectively achieve wider recognition. This paper reports the responses of 19 authors from a range of institutions and experience levels at the 2012 Australasian Association for Engineering Education (AAEE) annual conference to the landscape model.

The model stimulated dialogue around the nature of topics in our community and allowed participants to find a place to belong in the landscape. We argue that such a dialogue will not only help develop a community identity, important for a knowledge domain that is still emerging in Australian university but also support colleagues and postgraduate student seeking to participate in or move within it. We suggest that an understanding of the landscape could potentially dissipate the ultimately divisive tensions between scholars, practitioners and researchers. We argue that our community should provide an environment aimed at improving the quality of publications and the development of academics wherever they are on the landscape.

p.strong: Combining flipped instruction and multiple perspectives to develop cognitive and affective processes

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Curriculum Development
Author's preference: Oral
Keith Willey, Anne Gardner University of Technology, Sydney, Sydney, Australia

Flipped instruction is a form of blended learning that replaces transmission-based lectures with more participative, interactive and collaborative learning opportunities. Activities are typically undertaken before, during and after class, freeing in class time for student to engage in dialogue, and include assessment (typically formative) to allow them to evaluate their understanding and progress in meeting the desired learning outcomes. Flipping creates an opportunity for academics to provide more dynamic feedback to student, and to receive feedback from student about both the activities they are undertaking and what they don't yet understand. Hence, the learning environment is socially constructed as academics and student combine to influence the nature, focus, complexity and timing of subject activities. Social cognitive theory provides a way to frame our thinking about this learning context by foregrounding aspects such as the environment created for learning, as well as considering development of student self-efficacy and how to scaffold the processes for this development.

This paper reports the exploratory phase of an ongoing study investigating relationships between engagement, mastery of the subject concepts, affective outcomes and professional identity development in the context of flipped instruction. The study supported modification of our collaborative learning modelto explicitly provide multiple perspectives to assist student to overcome learning thresholds, develop disciplinary literacy, professional identity and expertise. In addition, it highlighted the impact of scaffolding and learning activities design on affective outcomes such as self-efficacy and includes the need for activities and assessments to be designed to enhance learning visibility.

p.strong: Impact of threshold exams on student learning

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Quality Assurance and Accreditation
Author's preference: Oral
Keith Willey, Anne Gardner University of Technology, Sydney, Sydney, Australia

Despite academic claims that all topics in their subject are requisite, student are often able to pass assessment tasks with unsatisfactory, and perhaps even no capacity to demonstrate learning in some topics. Furthermore, while undertaking an exam can highlight learning deficiencies there is often no assessable opportunity to address these learning gaps. The aim of our study was to investigate the impact of a two-stage examination process on student' motivation and approach to learning and its capacity to provide both assurance and feedback on their learning. The first stage of the process was a multiple-choice exam, with a pass mark of 80%, covering all requisite subject topics. student receive immediate feedback on their strengths and weaknesses when answering questions through the locally designed technology. An exam review was held one week after the threshold exam in which common misconceptions and misunderstandings were explored. This enabled student to review identified areas of weakness before attempting the second stage of the exam. The study demonstrated that a two-stage examination motivated student to learn and provided them with an opportunity to first identify and subsequently address learning gaps. However we found that student need assistance to change both their method and culture of learning with supporting scaffolding to better manage and benefit from the opportunities threshold exams provide.

p.strong: Improvement of the Engineering Student s Training inside University Laboratories through Quality Management Systems

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Curriculum Development
Author's preference: Poster
Luca Podesta', Gianluca Sforza University 'La Sapienza', Rome, Italy

This article analyzes the potentialities and the various consequences that may occur during engineering student s educational path when they undertake a training activities, both if it is a thesis work or an internship, in a laboratory implementing a Quality Management System (QMS).
This is important because it may change the job s organization (perspectives) and the problem solving approach, and it gives student a very important added value appreciated in workplaces.

First the key points of a QMS are analyzed and how these are related to training activities of the student. Even the economic aspects have been considered as a function of the quality objectives to be achieved.

Some case studies are presented, illustrating a series of processes developed in a laboratory of the Faculty of Civil and Industrial Engineering - University La Sapienza that were tested during the academic year.
Finally, some processes are illustrated in which student were able to complete the task training through internships and thesis following a training set in a context of quality.

p.strong: Connecting Higher Education, Business and Research to develop a Future Educational Ecosystem

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Industry involvement in EE
Author's preference: Oral
Ricardo Abdoel1, Sharda Kawarmala1, Ilona Verwaal1 1Fontys School of Engineering, Eindhoven, Noord Brabant, The Netherlands, 2Fontys CoE HTSM Objexlab, Eindhoven, Noord Brabant, The Netherlands

The Eindhoven region in the south of the Netherlands is the heart of the high-tech industry. The regional companies have understood that collaboration in manufacturing, development and innovation with suppliers is key to retaining a competitive position in the world. Fontys University is fully aware of the dynamics and significant (economic) potential of the high-tech manufacturing industry. Fontys plays an important role in the regional innovation system as an industry partner and it is leading the way in higher education in advanced emerging manufacturing technology. As such, Fontys has decided to collaborate with regional industry to invest in and develop a new Centre of Expertise focusing on high-tech manufacturing and materials. This new development will boost cooperation and partnerships on many different levels, helping to fulfil our stakeholder's different needs. In general, this model of public-private cooperation will contribute to our government's goals and Brainport's human capital agenda. The demand for more and better engineers is closely connected to curriculum development. Interesting enough due to technological development entrepreneurship plays an important role. This means that the engineers of the future must be equipped with more than just deep technical competences. Non-Technical competences as in communication skills, project management, group dynamics etc. becomes more important. The Eindhoven region is also very attractive for international student and knowledge workers. The cultural aspects should not be underestimated. In this paper we will investigate these different aspects and how to connect higher education to international operating high-tech businesses by collaborating and executing applied research

p.strong: Putting mathematics into a form that a non-engineers will understand

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Maths in EE
Author's preference: Oral

p.em: Institute of Technology Tallaght, Dublin, Ireland

body.p: A study of engineers practising in Ireland provides evidence for a requirement to better match the mathematics taught in engineering education with the mathematics required in engineering practice. In particular mathematical thinking has a greater relevance to engineers' work compared to mathematics contained in school and engineering curricula. A significant difference between engineering education and practice, highlighted by the study, is the social aspect of work compared to education. Tackling workplace problems is usually a team effort while in engineering education problem solving is mostly an individual effort. Engineers maintain that engineering education mostly imparts knowledge while the role of practising engineers is "to frame the problem correctly and maybe express it in maths, then they have to solve it and then they have to interpret the solution and communicate that to the decision maker". The study found that graduate engineers' difficulty communicating mathematics is a significant weakness of engineering education and consequently when engineers move from engineering education into engineering practice they do not realise their mathematical ability. The study also found that the ability to communicate mathematics and its relevance is the predominant characteristic of good mathematics teachers.

p.strong: TeachING-LearnING.EU Three years of improving German engineering education and what can be learned for Europe

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Curriculum Development
Author's preference: Oral

Dominik May1, Katharina Schuster3, A. Erman Tekkaya2, Anja Richert3, Sabina Jeschke3, Marcus Petermann4 1ZHB - TU Dortmund University, Dortmund, NRW, Germany, 2IUL - TU Dortmund University, Dortmund, NRW, Germany, 3IMA/ZLW and IfU - RWTH Aachen University, Aachen, NRW, Germany, 4FVT - Ruhr University Bochum, Bochum, NRW, Germany

Some people get allergy-like symptoms as soon as they hear the word Bologna . Stultifying bureaucracy, unbearable workload, annoying accreditation agencies or failed goals are just some exaggerated associations. But were the last 12 years really completely misled? TeachING-LearnING.EU - The Competence and Service Center for Teaching and Learning in Engineering Education has been seeking to use the reform as a catalyst for innovating German engineering education.
