Combining research with effective result oriented teacher coaching and strategic instruments for connecting stakeholders was the main approach throughout the years. Now after learning a lot and applying the knowledge, it seems inevitable to reflect on the previous activities and to build a roadmap for applying the findings in a broader context. This paper presents the major project-result by answering these questions:

(1) What are higher education researchers , teaching staff s, student , and employers individual perspectives on engineering education and how can they be involved in the improvement of engineering education effectively?
(2) How can Student centred teaching concepts be integrated effectively and what are challenges that are unique to engineering?
(3) How can large audience lectures be innovated and which communication technology can help doing so?
(4) The project has been running for three years - What were the major lessons learned on a meta-level and how can this be used to build a roadmap for upcoming projects and activities?
Answering these questions this papers deduces recommendations for future engineering education itself and future engineering education research in Europe.

p.strong: ALLES ING! Count me in! Using the Role Model Concept to Attract Pupils and student to Engineering Sciences

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: The Attractiveness of Engineering
Author's preference: Poster
Theresa Janssen, Natascha Strenger, Sulamith Frerich, Marcus Petermann Ruhr Universit? Bochum, NRW, Germany

While engineering graduates are highly sought-after in technology driven countries such as Germany, the numbers of freshman student especially non-traditional-student - in these subjects is still below that of other disciplines. Interpreting these numbers, it is argued that among the reasons for pupils reluctance to choose engineering sciences are intense curricula and high demands of those subjects. A different but apparently no less important factor in keeping pupils from studying engineering sciences is considered to be their rather low social acceptance and coolness factor.

At the Ruhr-University Bochum, the three engineering faculties (Civil and Environmental Engineering, Electrotechnology and Information Technology and Mechanical Engineering) have joined forces in 2013 and started a common initiative for attracting pupils and student to their study programs: ALLES ING!, an online platform that portraits student and scientific staff alike and introduces female engineers, teams and technical themes. Research topics (for Bachelor, Master, or doctoral theses) are presented by their respective authors and even career perspectives are depicted in videos of alumni at their actual workplace. The initiative is designed not only to attract new student, but also to increase the identification of those who are already studying at Bochum s engineering faculties with their subject. Functioning as role models, the people and topics in engineering sciences are presented basing on scientific facts, but never forgetting the importance of an attractive and interest-rousing presentation.

p.strong: The Global Engineer: the student' Standpoint

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: The Global Engineer
Author's preference: Either
Abheesha Busawon, Roger Penlington, Noel Perera, Jenna Tudor Northumbria University, Newcastle, UK

The concept of being a global engineers has become the subject of much debate within the engineering education and profession. The engineering sector is faced with new engineering challenges such as the need to address the impact of globalisation and sustainability, skills-gap, and the greening of the job market. It is therefore imperative to initiate a re-skilling of the curriculum starting from the student perspective to restore confidence in engineering.

This paper describes a project that is currently under way which sought to investigate how engineering undergraduates viewed professional recognition, whether they believe they have gained the important engineering attributes, their assessment of employability through their degree programme including future mobility, and how confident they are to compete within global markets.

The student acted as primary stakeholders in this project with participants coming from a range of backgrounds from the engineering undergraduate programme including Mechanical Engineering, Electrical Engineering and Computing within the Faculty of Engineering and Environment.

The survey carried out within the Faculty so far demonstrates that over half of student participants are confident about obtaining a job after graduating with the skills they have acquired. The findings also recognised opportunities to increase confidence in becoming competent global engineers and concept of mobility since only a minority of student have strong intentions of competing on the international job market.
The outcomes of this project hope to generate awareness to increase support for student to participate in dialogues surrounding these issues and promote the global engineering education.

p.strong: Setting up a New Culture of Teaching and Learning at the Technische Universit?Berlin: The Ziethen-Workshops

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Ethics and leadership
Author's preference: Oral
Patrick Thurian, Cornelia Raue Technische Universit?Berlin, Berlin, Germany

In 2012 the TU Berlin initiated the program "First class for our student" in order to improve the conditions of studying and teaching. The program supports a better academic staffing for all status groups as well as measures for didactic qualifications and counseling. The program has eight subprojects. The subproject "tu inspire" was designed as a qualification and reputation program for teaching and learning. In order to level higher teaching and learning at TU Berlins agenda, we decided to organize two retreats aiming for creating a guiding coalition. Hence in 2012 and in 2013, vice presidents, deans, deans of studies, awardees for good teaching, administrative staff as well as student and university didactic staff came together in Ziethen nearby Berlin for three days. The retreats were designed as strategic workshops that provided space for the various perspectives of the participants on teaching and learning and created a sense of common goals. First result are the declaration on teaching and learning ("Ziethener Manifest") drafted by the participants and the formation of eight working groups, e.g. "Improving communication within TU Berlin", "Teaching and learning: spreading, piloting and imparting new ways of teaching and learning among university teachers". All working groups are open to all members of TU Berlin to take part in this process of change. Due to this an avalanche effect is observed which seems to bring the university to a new culture of teaching and learning within the next years. result of the workshops and working groups will be presented.

p.strong: Enabling backchannel communication between a lecturer and a large class

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Technology in Learning
Author's preference: Oral
Mirjam Sophia Glessmer, Marc-Andr?ick, Patrick G??ch Hamburg University of Technology, Hamburg, Germany

Large classes make communication difficult between student and instructors. In a large lecture theater setting, the lecturer is situated far away from the student, and sitting in rows hinders group discussions and promotes anonymity. In a recent tutorial offered to some hundred student in such a setting, we realized that some of the challenges the student were experiencing and expressing to each other never made it to the instructor s attention and hence were not explicitly addressed.

To increase the instructor s awareness of the state of the student understanding and to reduce the threshold of asking questions in front of their peers, a backchannel tool was designed: a website where student can anonymously post questions. Those questions appear in real time at a moderator s screen, where they can be deleted or forwarded to the instructor so that the instructor can choose to address them at a suitable time.

Evaluation of a pilot run showed that student appreciate the opportunity to ask questions anonymously, and that instructors welcome the insights. Additionally, the record of questions helps to understand the student learning the data can be used as basis for learning analytics to see how the quality, quantity and type of questionsdevelops over time. We present this to discuss both the advantages and disadvantages of our approach, as well as the usefulness of the data as basis for learning analytics studies.

p.strong: Engineering Graduate Employability - an international comparison.

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: The Global Engineer
Author's preference: Oral
Tom Ridgman1, Mingzhen Liu2 1University of Cambridge, Cambridge, UK, 2University of Oxford, Oxford, UK

There has been a long history in the US and UK of criticism of the work readiness of new engineering graduates. The output of the many surveys tends to point to a familiar list of skill shortages, to a level where the surveys have become a self reinforcing piece of folk wisdom with little empirical supporting evidence. The Chinese HE system is rapidly expanding, 6.6 million fresh graduates left university in 2011, but China Post reported that it has never been harder for employers to find appropriate people; indicating that similar criticisms are emerging but not based on a historic perspective. This study was conducted to explore the Chinese industry's expectation for engineering graduates who constitute the largest proportion of graduates in China, but only 10% are considered employable. The findings were compared with UK studies which demonstrated that industry's expectation and also the effectiveness of the HE system are different. The Chinese industry's expectation for engineering graduates differed in a number of aspects such as the importance of working experience, preferred engineering disciplines and expected attributes etc. The comparison also showed that the effectiveness of the higher engineering education in the UK and China are different depending on certain aspects. These differences need to be further understood to determine whether producing Global engineers can be a reality.

p.strong: Democratic co-determination and responsibility of lecture content

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Active Learning
Author's preference: Poster
S?? Hansen, Jens B. Bennedsen Arhus University, Aarhus, Denmark

One of the most important challenges for us as instructors is to facilitate reflective behavior in our student in an attempt to achieve deep learning. Here follows that we want the student to engross themselves in the course material and to assume responsibility for their own learning. Traditional approach for university teaching is that the instructor presents some topic(s), where small exercises, such as TPS, clickers, minute paper etc. may be inlaid, however it is still the instructor that controls and ensures a strict path is taken. This is often perceived as being served "a meal" by the student.

A teaching methodology described by Herskin (http://samfundslitteratur.dk/user/9649/public-profile) addresses this challenge. Our design is concretization of this; it is a student centred approach, where it is up to the student to figure out what they want the instructor to talk about based on pre-planned lectures (curriculum, presentation and exercises). To facilitate this, the lecture starts by having the student work in groups of 10-15, where they discuss the combined material for 35-50 minutes. During the following intermission their feedback is used as a base line to create a talk that has emphasis on the parts they so desire.
In this paper we

li.p: present a didactical design inspired by Herskin
evaluate it in terms of the student view on:

p.strong: Introducing complexity into project management through multi-stakeholders interactions

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Active Learning
Author's preference: Oral

Myriam Le Goff-Pronost1, Bruno Vinouze1, Matthieu Arzel1, Antoine Beugnard1, Jean-Philippe Coupez1, Fran?s Gall1, Claire Lassudrie1, Michel Morvan1, Richard Na2, Didier Baux3 1Telecom Bretagne, Brest, France, 2Lyc?Vauban, Brest, France, 3Didier Baux Communication, Quimper, France

Telecom Bretagne is a French graduate engineering school in Information and Communication Technology. One of our ambitions is to train globally competitive technical managers able to cope with complex projects. To this end, we developed project based learning where student are in a practical situation close to their future career as an engineers. In this paper, we describe the project organisation and focus on the interactions between stakeholders (large student groups, customer, various experts, communications coach and methodology supervisors). student have to perform a techno-economical study with a great freedom as to their team organisation. student must discover the specific role of the stakeholders and must adjust the communication level to each interlocutor. Experts can be requested by the student to help them with technical matters. The methodology supervisors check if student methods are efficient, they point out dysfunctions and can provoke unexpected events. A communications coach can be requested by student to help in conflict management within the team or with the stakeholders. In order to quantitatively analyse the student progress in stakeholders interactions, a self assessment questionnaire was proposed before and after the course. This questionnaire covered interpersonal skills (teamwork, communication) and personal skills (adaptation to change, stress resistance). The student assessment shows a significant evolution of their management skills and their perception of complexity. Project organisation with many stakeholders and large student groups brings opportunities to illustrate complex situations. In the future, we aim to improve the experiment and analyse feedback aver a longer period.

p.strong: Preliminary evaluation of an intervention to increase student success of first year student in engineering education

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Education al Research Methods
Author's preference: Oral
Maartje van den Bogaard, Ellen Sjoer Delft University of Technology, Delft, The Netherlands

This paper reports on part of a qualitative study on student experiences with and perceptions of their educational environment in their first year in Delft University of Technology. The focus of this study are student experiences with an intervention designed specifically to increase student success in the first year of enrolment: the Exclusion of Reenrolment Rule. In this study a qualitative approach was used to collect data from a large sample of first year student representing 8 bachelor courses over the course of the first year. Outcomes of the study indicate that the intervention is not successful in the sense that few student feel challenged by it. At the same time the intervention is effective as student who are failing are quick to seek help. This qualitative approach turned out to be of value to learn about effectiveness of intervention such as the exclusion of reenrolment rule early on.

p.strong: Black boxes in electronics engineering labs

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Education al Research Methods
Author's preference: Oral

Pieter Coppens1 ,2, Johan Van den Bossche1 ,2, Mieke De Cock3 ,2 1Faculty of Engineering Technology, KU Leuven, Leuven, Belgium, 2LESEC, KU Leuven, Leuven, Belgium, 3Department of Physics and Astronomy, KU Leuven, Leuven, Belgium

Based on previous research [1-2], we reshaped a 2nd year electronics engineering lab on RC-filters. In the new setting, student have to prepare for the lab session by using a newly developed simulation to train them in oscilloscope reading and construction of a Bode plot. During the lab, a black box' approach is implemented to force student to think about the measuring procedure and the concepts related to these RC-filters.

Several groups of student were videotaped to analyse student' performance and activities in the lab.In the paper, we will briefly outline the analysis method of the videotapes, as well as its performance. We will use the result of the video analysis to verify the student' differences in activities in the new laboratory.
[1]Coppens, P., and De Cock, M. (2013). Exploring student' activities and learning in an analog electronics lab session. In 41th SEFI Annual Conference. Leuven.

[2]Coppens, P., Cock, M. De, and Kautz, C. (2012). Student Understanding of Filters in Analog Electronics Lab Courses. In 40th SEFI Annual Conference:Engineering Education 2020: Meet the Future. Thessaloniki.

p.strong: Bridging the skills gap in STEM industries

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Industry involvement in EE
Author's preference: Oral
Coorous Mohtadi1, Owen McAree1, Joachim Schlosser2 1MathWorks Ltd, Cambridge, UK, 2MathWorks Gmbh, Ismaning, Germany

The gap between skills of university graduates in engineering disciplines and expectations of industrial employers poses a number of challenges for both employers and university. Employers find that the new employees far from being able to contribute immediately need to be retrained in areas such as Model-Based Design that is used extensively in industry and not embraced fully in education. A recent survey of employers and academics in the UK performed by YouGov PLC demonstrates:

ul.li: Majority believe a gap exists between the skills of graduates and requirements of industry
To narrow this gap will potentially take a decade and will require collaboration between industry and university in curriculum development
60% of the respondents believe that project based learning approach can narrow this gap. In addition, 88% also conclude that workplace experience is vital.

body.p: Experience in cooperating with university and schools demonstrates that an effective solution requires many strands including:

ul.li: Assisting university in their endeavours to use new approach such as Project Based Learning in the engineering curricula
Supporting research programme and initiatives. These include endowing chairs and supporting senior researchers as well as continuous support of PhD level research programme.
Developing relevant curricula with high schools to ensure that there is a steady stream of candidates for STEM subjects
Encouraging and supporting extra-curricular national and international student contests.

body.p: The paper sets out the current view of the "gap" from industrialist's perspective and will demonstrate that experience of using many of the mitigation strategies have a significant impact in narrowing it.

p.strong: The development of a bridge course Numerical Analysis into the e-learning environment MUMIE

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Maths in EE
Author's preference: Oral
Joanna Daudt, Kees Vuik, Fons Daalderop, Robert van Kints TU Delft, Delft, The Netherlands

In the frame work of student mobility bridge courses for incoming master student from other engineering schools, become more and more important. Bridge courses are meant to narrow the gap between the knowledge and understanding from student and the demands necessary in the advanced math master courses. Using an e-learning environment makes the bridge course flexible and open to adjustments and extension.

Together with three other university partners (Aalto University Finland, KTH Sweden and TU Berlin), the TU Delft has made a start end 2012 with the development of a bridge course Numerical Analysis. Other bridge courses are developed by the other partners (Scientific Computing with Matlab, Probability and Statistics, bridge material Math for incoming bachelor student).

MUMIE is an open source e-learning platform. It uses modern web technology, is written in java and supports any kind of multimedia components (interactive visualizations, audio, video). MUMIE is multi-lingual supporting presently German and English. Learners need nothing but a standard browser. Authors write their content in an comfortable authoring environment based on an eclipse plugin and write mathematical text in the standard Latex (MUMIE-dialect).
In this paper we report the result and evaluation of a pilot study performed in May 2013 where the developed material was offered to 100 student from the Civil Engineering Department.

The pilot was successfully implemented, covering the theory for non-linear equations and numerical quadrature together with two homework exercises for bisection, two exercises for fixed point methods and an exercise for integral approximation.

p.strong: Engineering positioning test in Flanders: a powerful predictor for study success?

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: The Attractiveness of Engineering
Author's preference: Oral
Jef Vanderoost, Riet Callens, Joos Vandewalle, Tinne De Laet KU Leuven, Leuven, Belgium

A new positioning test for BSc Engineering was broadly and uniformly implemented in Flanders in the summer of 2013. The non-mandatory test measures the ability of future engineering student to solve engineering problems and compares a student's mathematical skills with the required previous knowledge. The positioning test was organized twice during the summer of 2013 and drew 859 participants across three Flemish university. The resulting scores were normally distributed with 56% passing the test. Of all student enrolled for the Bsc of Engineering at KU Leuven, 51% passed the position test, 22% failed, and 27% didn't participate.

Our goal is to relate the study result to the score on the positioning test, determine the predictive power of the positioning test, discover different student groups that show similar evolution, and determine the impact of the positioning test on enrolment. We analyzed the result of the positioning test, intermediate tests, and the exams in January (1st semester).

The study leads to the following conclusions: student with a score lower than 10/20 have a low chance to obtain good result in January (77% badly fails). Their prior knowledge deficiency can't be re-mediated in only one semester.

While passing the positioning test increases the chance on study success it Is not no guarantee for study success. Other features such as motivation, study effort, study method, and stress-handling are important.

ul.li: Despite its predictive power the positioning test does not succeed in advising student that badly fail the test against enrolment.

p.strong: Diversity and the academic engineering positioning test in Flanders: Impact on female student and student with disabilities

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Issues of Gender and Diversity
Author's preference: Oral
Jef Vanderoost, Riet Callens, Joos Vandewalle, Tinne De Laet KU Leuven, Leuven, Belgium

A new positioning test for BSc Engineering was broadly and uniformly implemented in Flanders in the summer of 2013. The non-mandatory test measures the ability of future engineering student to solve engineering problems and compares a student's mathematical skills with the required previous knowledge. The goal of this paper is to study the impact of the positioning test for two target groups: student with disabilities and female student.

The positioning test uses an inclusive approach regarding student with disabilities. One of the findings it 77% of the student with disabilities that entered the bachelor studies passed the positioning test (compared to the general success rate of 75%), showing that the inclusive approach is successful.

The study regarding the target group of female student leads to these conclusions: Female student have a significantly lower success rate than male student. This can be explained by the number of hours in mathematics in secondary education.

Regarding the impact of negative marking female student have a significantly higher number of blank answers. This is in accordance with literature, which attributes this effect to the more risk-averse behaviour of female student.

Female student score lower on questions requiring graphical and spatial reasoning. But, they score higher on questions requiring analytic skills and questions testing the application of mathematical theorems taught in secondary school.
The impact of positioning test result on the decision whether or not to enrol in the BSc Engineering studies does not differ significantly between male and female student.

p.strong: From word-clouds to video: IT tools in the service of learning

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Active Learning
Author's preference: Oral
Pedro Neto1, Bill Williams1 ,2 1Setubal Polytechnic Institute, Setubal, Portugal, 2CEG-IST, Instituto Superior T?ico, Universidade de Lisboa, Lisbon, Portugal

Working within a theoretical framework drawn from Etienne Wenger s technology stewardship concept, the authors describe six technology-based approach they have implemented to facilitate active and collaborative learning. First they describe a procedure to employ Word Cloud technology to enhance learner formative reflection in the classroom. Then ways of using a Learning Management System in tandem with online Self and Peer Assessment tools to enhance collaborative learning in groups and between groups is addressed. In addition, the authors describe how MS Powerpoint can be used by learners along with webcams and free video editing tools to enable student team preparation of evaluated video presentations.
The paper describes the tools used, the setting up of the activities and data-gathering procedures used with first year undergraduate civil engineering student
Keywords: technology stewardship, active learning; collaborative learning, IT tools, pedagogy, word clouds

p.strong: Curriculum Development to Sustain Retention and Graduation Rates

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Curriculum Development
Author's preference: Oral

p.em: New Jersey Institute of technology, Newark, New Jersey, USA

body.p: At New Jersey Institute of Technology the first year curriculum for the engineering student all contained Calculus I, Physics I with Laboratory and General Chemistry I rounding out to a total of 17 credits in the first semester. The second semester contained 19 credits including Calculus II, Physics II and Laboratory, General Chemistry II and Laboratory as well as Computer Science. Although the retention rates for chemical engineers were not terrible (88%), we strived to improve and decided on three modifications that we anticipated would increase the retention rates. In the fall 2011, the chemical engineering curriculum was modified in order to sustain retention and graduation rates by making three deliberate changes. Firstly, the broadly accepted notion that engineering physics is to be calculus based suggest that Physics I should be offered subsequent to Calculus I. This change was implemented by swapping physics with a social science in the first semester. The second step was to ensure connections between the fundamentals of engineering design (FED-101) course and the writing course. The third change required moving Physics II to the penultimate semester in which the subject matter would be prerequisite for the process control course. As a result we observed that our retention rate increased to 93%. Simultaneously, the physics department has been also observing that the physics II course is now composed of more mature student that are engaged as if the material is more relevant to some project or course work.

p.strong: Reforming Engineering Education - A feasibility analysis of Models for Innovation

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Curriculum Development
Author's preference: Oral
Anders Berglund1, Sofia Ritz1, Jonte Bernhard2 1KTH Royal Institute of Technology, Stockholm, Sweden, 2Link??g University, Norrkoping, Sweden

The capability to innovate is an important skill for engineers, thus stressing the critical issue of educating for innovation at technical university. This paper investigates the feasibility of four different models for implementing and practising new content in engineering education. Implementation efforts are looked at revealing systematic constraints and pitfalls, and also evaluating these approach from the perspective of innovation capabilities and the desired effects from changes in education. The different models can be categorized as bottom-up and top-down approach depending on actors' roles in the education system. The top-down and bottom-up approach are also categorized in accordance to the width of the approach: programmatic changes with new content in many courses and specialized changes with new courses addressing the desired content and capabilities. A critical analysis is made of the four models intercepting specific learning elements that can be elevated to facilitate innovation in courses and programs. The critical analysis not only relates to educational values, but also relates more specifically to the needs of teaching and training innovation and consequently to developing innovation capabilities. This leads us to discuss the practical epistemologies involved in engineering practice in general and in innovation in particular; engineering as an art and as a science and both are essential. Finally arguments on how to actually reform education are addressed, with attention on leveraging innovation as a key driver to excel and challenge the learning experiences faced by current and future student.

p.strong: Deeper approach to learning with peer-assessment

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: student as partners
Author's preference: Oral
Katja Vahtikari, Anne L?eenm?, Panu Kiviluoma Aalto University, Espoo, Finland

The focus of this paper is on peer assessment and the effect of assessment on learning. In addition, student' insights and experiences of peer-assessment are explored. The authors' goal is to use assessment as a tool for guiding student' work to a desirable direction. Letting student get involved in assessment and defining the assessment criteria helps them take responsibility of their learning and build up confidence, commitment, and ownership. Could peer assessment encourage the student to reflect on questions such as am I doing the right thing or is this enough, and, as a result, activate them to analyse and enhance their performance?

The student' perspectives on assessment were collected with a survey and feedback from courses taught by the authors. For example, student were asked how they experience and value peer assessment, what is its effect on learning, what kind of support and instructions are needed, and do they feel competent assessing their peers. This paper introduces experiences from three courses at the schools of Engineering, Electrical Engineering, and Chemical Technology of Aalto University. The courses are Experimental methods, Integrated Interior Wooden Surfaces, and Astronomical View of the World. They vary in extent both in terms of duration and credits. The smallest course is three credits (82h) and the largest five credits (135h). The number of student varies from 20 to 60.

p.strong: The acceptance of using an annotation approach on Tablet PC-based e-book in a mechanical engineering course

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Technology in Learning
Author's preference: Poster

Chia-Ju Liu1, Hsin-Chin Chen2, Ming-Hsun Shen1, Yueh-Min Huang2, Tzone-I Wang2 1Graduate Institute of Science Education and Environmental Education, National Kaohsiung Normal University, Kaohsiung, Taiwan, 2Department of Engineering Science, National Cheng Kung University, Tainan, Taiwan

Tablet PCs have become prevalent learning devices, widely used by learners in a variety of mobile learning environments nowadays. Many studies have explored the feasibility of using Tablet PCs in the learning engineering courses, especially those with complex graphics or operation processes. Of them, mechanism is a fundamental course to introduce the concepts of the mechanical components in the field of mechanical engineering. For the course, printed books have been a major media for student to learn in the traditional classrooms. However, printed books have their limitations in presenting scalable architectures or the dynamic process of mechanical operation thoroughly, compromising the learning interest and effectiveness. In order to enhance student learning motivation and understanding of learning Mechanism, this study proposes using the Tablet PC-based e-book, which supports text, graphics, video and interactive functions to facilitate student an adaptive learning environment. Furthermore, interactive annotation functions were constructed on this interactive e-book learning environment to assist learners in highlighting important potions of the learning content for effective future review. To verify the effectiveness of the proposewd approach, a questionnaire was developed to evaluate learning satisfaction, learning interest and technology acceptance. The findings indicated that adopting the interative e-book system literally elicted student interest in learning the Mechanism course, where many architecture concepts and dynamicprocesses of mechanical operation became more illustrative, especially by the aid of annotation functions provided.

p.strong: A model of critical reflectionwithin awork based learning programme

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Continuing Engineering Education and Lifelong learning
Author's preference: Oral

The increasing use of active learning activities for the education, training and development of engineers has brought into focus the need to understand the ways in which engineers learn from experience across a range of environments. Since 2006 the Engineering Council has been leading their Gateways Project which uses work based learning, a particular form of active learning, to accelerate and make more widely accessible the opportunity to develop and demonstrate professional engineering competences by their incorporation into a range of academic programme. However during the development of both MSc and BEng programme within this Project it became apparent that existing models of learning could not adequately articulate the learning experience being generated by the programme. In order to maximise the benefits to learners from a the wide range of backgrounds and differing engineering environments by fully utilising the inherent flexibility of the programme a more representative model was needed. Critical reflection on the experience of developing the programme provided the basis for the development of that model.

This paper presents the findings of that critical reflection and the resulting model that has been generated as a result. The paper includes a discussion of the role of critical reflection within the model and the impact of its role on the study experiences of learners. So as to elucidate the model's relevance, the paper includes a short case study aspect of one learner's experience. Finally the paper concludes with description of the current work to further enhance the model s utility.

p.strong: The Effects of using Synonyms Annotation for English Video Subtitles on Content Understanding, Vocabulary Learning, and Cognitive Loading

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Technology in Learning
Author's preference: Oral
Tzone I WANG, In Hong Wu National Cheng Kung University, Taiwan, Tainan, Taiwan

Video watching is now a popular way of learning for many disciplines. Many researches have proved that learners may achieve better performance when watching proper videos than taking traditional classroom courses. The Internet now makes it easier for learners to access online videos with information on various new technology for self-learning. However, for English as Foreign Language learners, their limited volume of English vocabulary might pose as a barrier to understand videos with difficult contents and subtitles. Researchers have been using dictionary style full explanations on the vocabulary of video subtitles for learners while they are watching videos. Cognitive load would increase when a learner has to stops to read the full explanations of unfamiliar words in the subtitle while watching a video; researchers has shown that increased cognitive load would lead to the reduction of a learner s performance.

This study propose a new method to reduce learners cognitive load when learning with videos. When a learner clicks on an unfamiliar vocabulary in the subtitle of a playing video the video stops and the method displays as many as possible the synonyms, instead of the full explanations, of the vocabulary for the learner. To see whether the method is feasible and effective, this study conducts two experiments on college student using videos of different difficulty levels. The experiment result confirm that the simple way of annotating vocabulary with synonyms not only reduces cognitive load of learners but also increases their understanding of video contents and volume of vocabulary effectively.

p.strong: Mid Project Milestone for the QUEECA TEMPUS Project: First result and Rising Expectations.

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Quality Assurance and Accreditation
Author's preference: Oral
Claudio Borri, Michele Betti, Elisa Guberti Universit?egli Studi di Firenze - Civil and Environ. Engineering Dpt., Firenze, Italy

The QUEECA (Quality of Engineering Education in Central Asia) TEMPUS project main aim is that one of setting up and starting implementing a system of quality assurance (QA) of engineering education in Central Asia (CA), finalised to the accreditation of engineering programme by the award of the EUR-ACE quality label on the basis of the EUR-ACE Framework Standards and related quality requirements and procedures. The project also takes advantage of experience in the EHEA (through ENAEE) and current efforts in Central Asia countries. More specifically QUEECA aims to use as basis the EUR-ACE Framework Standards (EAFS) and related quality requirements and procedures, awarding the EUR-ACE quality label to the accredited programme. At the present moment (March 2014) the project has arrived to the mid project milestone and time has come for a thorough internal evaluation taking into account the first encouraging result so far obtained, such as the creation of the Kyrgyz Society for engineering Education (October 2013) and the rising expectations from the concerned parties. The paper shortly introduces the QUEECA TEMPUS project and reports about the achieved result and the activities scheduled for the next moths. Finally the reasons why the project is to be considered a pilot one, introducing the EUR-ACE system outside the European Union with an easy replicable model are also given.

p.strong: Electronic Engineering PBL at the Design Engineering School of Valencia, Spain

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Active Learning
Author's preference: Poster

Enrique Ballester Sarrias, Javier Ib?z Civera, Rafael Masot Peris, Miguel Alca??Fillo, Jos?arrigues Baixauli, Jos?icente Lid??oger, Luis M. S?hez Ruiz Universitat Polit?ica de Valencia, Valencia, Spain

Project based learning methodology(PBL) is one of the most effective methods of teaching where student not only develop the scientific and technical abilities inherent to the corresponding subjects but it also fosters knowledge about organization and management at the same time that it promotes a number of social abilities as valued today as teamwork, leadership, communication, planning, etc.

This methodology is widely used and tested in many disciplines and it is well-known the UK approach to Engineering Project-Based Learning White Paper sponsored by the Bernard M, Gordon MIT Engineering Leadership Program, MIT

In this paper we describe PBL experiences carried out in two subjects in two different degrees of the School of Design Engineering ETSID at Valencia (Spain), namely in the subject of "Digital Electronics" at the BEng in Electronics and Control Engineering and in "Electronics Technology" at the BEng in Aerospace Engineering degree.

student do practical work in a consistent design of an electronic system in groups of two or three student. Teachers propose a project list with an adequate difficulty to the level of knowledge of student and a reasonable execution time after that, in a first step, the objectives and specifications of the prototype are clearly defined.
In all cases, the projects done by the student, end with the construction of prototypes which are openly exposed to the public in a special session.

p.strong: Innovating Engineering Education: The RVS Approach: An Empirically Grounded Method to Improved Practice and Enhanced Student Experience

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Continuing Engineering Education and Lifelong learning
Author's preference: Oral
Robin Clark, Jane Andrews Aston University, Birmingham, UK

In seeking to address issues associated with difficulties in attracting, recruiting and retaining student onto engineering programme, the paper authors set about developing a bespoke learning and teaching approach that would meet the learning needs and expectations of student, whilst providing a sound pedagogical basis upon which engineering could be taught. Building on Higher Education theory, and grounded in Engineering Education Research and Practise, an approach was developed in which three key components were identified as pivotal to Student Success within Engineering: Relationship: Variety: and, Synergy.

The RVS approach has been developed and tested over a number of years using a mixed methodological approach within an action research design. This paper presents the research findings in such a way so as to highlight the value of empirically grounded engineering education practice.

When taken together the three components of the RVS approach result in an innovative approach to engineering education that argues that Relationships + Variety + Synergy = Student Success (R+ V + S = S2). Taking each component of the approach in turn, the discussion focuses on how engineering educators can use each of these components to bring together pedagogic, discipline-related, socio-environmental and individual factors to address the challenges associated with engineering education.

p.strong: Tackling Transition! Peer Mentoring in Engineering Education - A UK Perspective

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Education al Research Methods
Author's preference: Oral
Jane Andrews, Robin Clark Aston University, Birmingham, UK

Grounded in the research findings of a study which examined the perceptions of engineering student peer mentors and mentees, this discussion paper critically examines the pedagogic and managerial issues encountered in developing and rolling out a bespoke peer mentoring programme aimed at reducing first year attrition in Engineering. Starting with the research question "Does peer mentoring improve engineering student' transition into university?' the study looked closely at two groups of engineering student as they progressed from freshers' week into the first year of their studies.

Following an Action Research Design and utilising an approach to Peer Mentoring developed out of a large international study (Clark and Andrews, 2013; Andrews and Clark, 2011), a mixed methodological approach was utilised to examine student' perceptions of the value of peer mentoring during transition into engineering. This paper presents the findings of the first research cycle', critically discussing how the study continues to shape and guide practice.

The discussion will focus on the social, academic and professional aspects of student transition into university, highlighting the challenges faced by engineering student.Focusing specifically on the challenges associated with studying engineering the discussion considers how the unknown' nature of the discipline can be particularly disconcerting for new student. It focuses on the unique role played by peer mentoring in helping new student overcome the barriers and challenges of the first term in university, putting forward an empirically grounded model of Peer Mentoring for use in Engineering Faculties.

p.strong: integrated project design for Civil Engineering Master in Oporto University

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Engineering Design
Author's preference: Oral
B?ara Rangel1, Fernando Brand?Alves2 1Engineering Faculty Of University of Porto, Porto, Portugal, 2Engineering Faculty Of University of Porto, Porto, Portugal

The current difficulties in the Construction Industry have been confirming the urgent interdisciplinary between all the design disciplines, from engineering to architecture. The required high levels of building efficiency and the optimization of the building process are increasing the demands on the accuracy of projects. The project is no longer a sum of contributes, but a design methodology that combines the answers to all the different requisites of the building, an INTEGRATED PROJECT. This multidisciplinary approach to the design problems is only possible if it s present in the design process from the first moment. This implicit complicity is only possible if it starts in the university education, searching for the common language of construction.

In recent years of Civil Engineering Master the discipline of Architecture, has been showing to future engineers this common territory, the construction grammar. Different construction technology imply specific design principals and rules. Different structural systems imply different architectural design. In the lectures, through the architectural history is searched the design lexicon of the different technology. In laboratory, studding real project, making construction models, visiting working sites and talking with architects and engineers, are given the design tools of this integrated project methodology. This article aims to present the experience of recent years developed this course in order to contribute to the increasingly urgent intersection of architecture and engineering.

p.strong: An open approach to educational resource development with a specific example from structural engineering

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Technology in Learning
Author's preference: Oral
Liam Comerford, Marco De Angelis, Adam Mannis, Michael Beer, Ioannis Kougioumtzoglou University of Liverpool, Liverpool, UK

A detailed account of how an interactive learning software package was developed to address a specific knowledge gap amongst undergraduate engineers at the University of Liverpool is presented in this paper. A primary objective, established from the outset, was not only to meet the needs of the local university, but to also consider dissemination and applicability of the resource for other institutions. There were three main objectives: First, the software needed to teach the subject matter with little or no additional input from the lecturer. Second, a system was required to ensure student completed a list of tasks (interactive problems / questions) set in the software, and this could be checked. Finally the software needed to be as accessible as possible for other institutions, home and abroad. The software package takes the form of a presentation with a series of in-built interactive elements. These elements consist of simulated experiments and questions, requiring input before the user may continue. The primary purpose of these tasks is to keep the student engaged with the material on-screen, i.e. they cannot complete each stage unless they read and understand the task properly. The development team partnered with a number of external institutions, thereby providing a network of academics to offer feedback at every stage. This gave rise to an iterative development procedure, through which the resource has been able to expand from being a narrow institutional-specific application, to now become a comprehensive tool with far-reaching use by others across the international engineering community.

p.strong: Computer based examinations at Politecnico di Torino

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Maths in EE
Author's preference: Oral
Anita Tabacco1, Paolo Boieri1, Giorgio Santiano1 ,2 1Politecnico di Torino, Torino, Italy, 2C.S.I Piemonte, Torino, Italy

The computer tool is becoming increasingly important in authoring, delivering and reporting examinations in the form of multiple choice tests, in particular in the presence of a large number of student. At Politecnico di Torino the Moodle platform is mainly used for Admission Test for Engineering programme, to check the language level of knowledge (English and Italian language for foreign student). Recently it was also used in the context of the course of Mathematical Analysis I (about 5000 student in 20parallel courses); as we describe in this presentation, the choice of a computer based test resulted in the following: a deep review of the course settings and methodology, designed to ensure a greater homogeneity of content between parallel courses; a thorough analysis of the subjects of the verification and of the structure of the test to be administered; the adaptation of the Moodle platform for the needs of Mathematics (for example, entering formulas written in Latex) and a good integration with the Portale della Didattica , the access point to all services related to the teaching of the Politecnico di Torino granted to student and professors.
The result of this four year work, the impact on student and development prospects of this experience are also discussed.

strong.i: Professional knowledge, skills and competencies of the new graduates and the engineering professionals comparison of the significance in working-life

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Continuing Engineering Education and Lifelong learning
Author's preference: Oral
Pirre Hyotynen1, Sanja Mursu1, Jussi-Pekka Teini2 ,1 1Academic Engineers and Architects in Finland - TEK, Helsinki, Finland, 2Student Union of Tampere University of Technology, Tampere, Finland

Academic Engineers and Architects in Finland - TEK has conducted surveys for M.Sc. graduates of technology or architecture since the early eighties. Nowadays the surveys are made in close cooperation with the Finnish university providing higher education in technology. In addition to those surveys TEK has also conducted surveys on professional development of academic engineers and architects in Finland. The survey on professional development has been conducted six times since 2002. The aim of the survey is to provide knowledge on the needs, attitudes and possibilities for professional development. The information from these two surveys provides TEK an important perspective on the development of engineering education as well as further professional development.

The aim of this paper is to present an insight into how the knowledge, skills and competencies of the newly graduated engineers have developed through the engineering education and due to working experience gained during studies.

Secondly, the paper compares the importance of the knowledge, skills and competencies of the new graduates with those of the engineering professionals who have a minimum of 5 years of post-graduate working experience.

This practice-based paper aims at presenting the important working-life skills and competencies in the field of engineering as well as the skills and competencies that should be emphasized in engineering education and further professional development.

p.strong: The role of educational technology and learning spaces in electrical engineering education - a case study at Aalto University School of Electrical Engineering

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Technology in Learning
Author's preference: Oral
Kirsti Keltikangas, Jari J. H?inen Aalto University School of Electrical Engineering, Espoo, Finland

student of engineering are increasingly using technology in their life. Most of the first-year student have their own laptops when entering university. The capabilities of the student' mobile phones can be far better than of the academic staff. student are connected to the internet with their equipment wherever they are. In addition, the generations who enter university in the next years are very talented in using different types of social media and internet services since their early childhood.

However, engineering education and its curriculum design is undoubtedly at least one step behind the student' current state. The technology used by the student in various spaces-not only in formal teaching ones-should be taken into account and its opportunities integrated into engineering education. At present, the current spaces used in teaching are often old-fashioned lecture theatres not equipped with state-of-the-art technology. The academic staff does use sufficiently mobile and online learning as an option when developing their courses.

A case study (n=236) was completed at Aalto University School of Electrical Engineering on how much engineering student use technology in their formal and informal learning. The survey covered the spaces used for learning as well. The result will gain insight into the student' thinking and will help teachers in the curriculum design. The result will also help the campus development managers in planning the renovation of the School's teaching spaces to support modern ways of learning.

p.strong: Tools to see with: Investigating the role of experimental technology for student learning in the laboratory

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Technology in Learning
Author's preference: Oral

BACKGROUND: student experience of the world in the laboratory is not a direct experience, human world, but a mediated experience, human tool world, shaped by the use of physical and symbolic tools. Technology is used as agencies of observations, i.e. as tools for collection and processing of physical data. However, the role of experimental technology for student learning in the laboratory is largely neglected in educational research. If technology are studied at all, it is often seen as being synonymous with studying the role of computers.

METHODS: student interaction in different physics and electric circuit labs, with different experimental technology, was recorded using digital camcorders. The videotaped data were used to detect typical interactional patterns. Particularly interesting parts of these sessions were transcribed to allow for detailed examination of interactional patterns.

result: In some cases the technology were used as tools to see the world with and some aspects of the world were put in the foreground. In other cases the technology in itself become the focus of attention and no, or inadequate, connection to the world was made. The role of the technology for student learning depended in some cases on the affordances of the technology used, but in other cases it depended on the pedagogical design.

CONCLUSION: Some experimental technology are more effective for facilitating learning by being effective tools to see with. However, for the effective use of technology the educational design is important and no technology is effective independently of the pedagogy used.

p.strong: Teaching self-awareness, diversity and reflection to support an integrated engineering curriculumaugmented with problem and scenario-based learning.

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Active Learning
Author's preference: Oral
Emanuela Tilley1, Jan Peters2, John E. Mitchell1 1UCL Engineering, London, UK, 2Katalytik, Christchurch, UK

A newfound student-centred Strengths Programme is currently being designed to provide student with a set of tools and the vocabulary to help them identify, explore, question, utilise,develop and reflect on their personal strengths and natural talents throughout their undergraduate engineering career. Through such exercise, student become familiar with a common language, used by employers, and obtain a heightened awareness of each other's potential when contributing to shared team goals. It will equip them with the ability to deal with and possibly prevent problems associated with leadership and assignment of roles, division of responsibility, time management and communication often experienced when working in teams. Additionally, addressing this level of self-awareness, student build mutual respect and motivation; the programme is designed to produce graduates that are more easily attuned to the values shared by top employers in diversity and inclusivity. StrengthsFinder2.0, published by GallupPress, is a strengths-based personal profiling and self-assessment tool that is introduced and explored to give the student a chance at understanding the type of engineering activities they enjoy and feel they can excel in. Helping to realise their unique potential to successfully take on leadership roles and understand the value in pursuing roles of leadership beyond authority', is also regarded as a pivotal motive for a revamp and redesign of the current engineering curriculum. Positive feedback and enthusiasm to get involved as Champions' for various aspects of the Strengths Programme have been bestowed by current student who have undertaken isolated pilots aligned with existing Year I problem-based learning modules.

p.strong: A statistical method for assessing teaching effectiveness based on non-identical pre- and post-tests

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Education al Research Methods
Author's preference: Oral
Julie Direnga, Dion Timmermann, Andrea Brose, Christian Kautz Hamburg University of Technology, Hamburg, Germany

Diagnostic tests and concept inventories are widely used in science and engineering education to monitor the effectiveness of teaching [1]. Often, identical tests are given before and after instruction, allowing direct comparison of respective scores [2]. However, in many introductory engineering courses, post-tests require familiarity with technical terminology and are therefore not feasible as pre-tests. Conversely, pre-tests that measure prerequisite knowledge but do not use technical terms may also not sufficiently cover the topics taught. In many cases, this discourages the use of identical pre- and post-tests. For identical pre- and post-tests, a relative learning gain factor has been proposed [3]. This relative gain has been used to establish the difference in effectiveness of traditional and active-learning approach [3]. In case of non-identical pre- and post-tests, a new approach has to be developed to compare the effectiveness of various teaching methods. We propose a statistical method for treating result from non-identical tests to assess and compare the influence of instruction. We test this method on an 8-year data set and critically discuss the result and validity. A comparison to established measures for teaching effectiveness is made.

[1] http://www.cihub.org [2] Steif, P. S., and Hansen, M. (2006). Comparisons between performances in a statics concept inventory and course examinations. International Journal of Engineering Education, 22(5), 1070. [3] Hake, R. R. (1998). Interactive-engagement versus traditional methods: A six-thousand-student survey of mechanics test data for introductory physics courses. American journal of Physics, 66(1), 64-74.

p.strong: An Insight to Global Engineering Challenges: Study and Analysis

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: student as partners
Author's preference: Oral

Rohit Kandakatla1, Joseph Packhem2, David D. Delaine3, Dhinesh Balaji Radhakrishnan4, Claudio Freitas5 1KG Reddy college of Engineering and Technology, Hyderabad, Andhra Pradhesh, India, 2Marquette University, Milwaukee, WI, USA, 3University of Sao Paolo, S?Paulo, SP, Brazil, 4University of Petroleum and Energy Studies, Dehradun, India, 5State University of Campinas, S?Paulo, SP, Brazil

Academics across the globe have been constantly improving Engineering education methodologies for many years. There have been many organizations and, initiatives that have come up for this very purpose. International Federation of Engineering Education Societies (IFEES) and Student Platform for Engineering Education Development (SPEED) are two such organization which work to the improve the quality of engineering education provided to the student. While both these organizations work for the same cause, they take a completely different approach. IFEES concentrates on a more top-down approach where as SPEED believes in a bottom-top approach giving student the role to bring about a change in the system. This paper portrays one initiative that IFEES and SPEED have taken together to analyze the various engineering problems currently faced by student across the globe. This analysis is based on a survey which is provided to student from many countries to raise the various issues, problems and challenges they are facing in the current education system. The result of this analysis will be used by both IFEES and SPEED separately, which will be addressed later in their respective approach to benefit the student fraternity. This analysis will also provide a comparison between the various engineering trends and methodologies practiced in different countries.

p.strong: DEVELOPMENT OF AN ENVIRONMENTAL AND RESOURCES ENGINEERING LEARNING

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Curriculum Development
Author's preference: Either

Enrica Caporali1, Claudio Borri1, Atanasko Tuneski2 1Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering, University of Firenze, Firenze, Italy, 2Faculty of Mechanical Engineering, Ss. Cyril and Methodius University, Skopje, Macedonia

The European Commission promotes the TEMPUS - Trans European Mobility Programme for University Studies in order to contribute to the creation of an area of cooperation in higher education between the European Union and the Partner Countries (PC). Modernisation of curricula in academic disciplines is one of the TEMPUS priority themes. DEREL - Development of Environment and Resources Engineering is a TEMPUS project leaded by the University of Firenze (UNIFI), Italy, for the period 10/2010 - 06/2014. The DEREL Consortium consists of 11 university (4 EU and 7 PC), and 7 non-academic institutions. The project introduced a new, up to date, postgraduate second level curriculum in Environment and Resources Engineering at DEREL PC university: Ss Cyril and Methodius University in Skopje - UKIM (FYR of Macedonia), University of Novi \Sad - UNS (Serbia) and Polytechnic University of Tirana - PUT (Albania), based on the European Credit Transfer System and in accordance with the Bologna Process, following the conditions for setting up a Double Postgraduate Degree. The project also implemented a sustainable regional network aimed to offer lifelong learning seminars for environment and resources engineering education and training of interested stakeholders, and to organize workshops focused on strengthening the links in the knowledge triangle: environment education-innovation-research. The three agreements between UNIFI with UKIM, with UNS, and with PUT for the establishment of shared educational paths in the environmental programs, aimed at awarding double degree titles between UNIFI and DEREL PC university, is one of the significant concluding objectives of the project.

p.strong: Environmental engineering education: examples of accreditation and quality assurance

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Quality Assurance and Accreditation
Author's preference: Either
Enrica Caporali, Marcantonio Catelani, Giampaolo Manfrida, Juna Valdiserri School of Engineering, University of Firenze, Firenze, Italy

Environmental engineers respond to the challenges posed by a growing population, intensified land-use, natural resources exploitation as well as rapidly evolving technology. The environmental engineers must develop technically sound solutions with the aims of maintaining or improving environmental quality, complying with public policy, and optimizing the utilization of resources. The globalization of challenges and problems to be faced leads to the globalization of the engineering profession which requires not only the capacity to communicate in a common technical language, but also the assurance of an adequate and common level of technical competences, knowledge and understanding. The application of the accreditation model EUR-ACE, and of the National Italian Degree Courses Accreditation System to the multidisciplinary first cycle degree in Civil, Building and Environmental Engineering and the more specific second cycle degree in Environmental Engineering carried out at the University of Firenze is presented. Particularly, the critical issues to assure the quality and the status of environmental engineering graduates, in terms of applying knowledge capacities and technical innovative competences, according to the more engineering focused EUR-ACE skill descriptors as well as to the Dublin descriptors, are compared. In addition, the involvement of the student and the professional working world in the definition of learning outcomes and expected skills, the assessment of the system for educating engineers in communicating knowledge and understanding, making informed judgments and choices, capacities to lifelong learning and the promotion of innovative aspects related to the environmental engineering education are further investigated.

p.strong: Course Project My future individual educational trajectory as a Basis for the Personality-oriented Professional Training

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Curriculum Development
Author's preference: Oral
Olga Belyaeva, Alla Frolkova, Valeriy Solomonov Lomonosov Moscow University of Fine Chemical Technology (MUTHT), Moscow, Russia

This paper describes an investigation of the impact of first-year student' motivation towards conceptual understanding of purposes of their individual curriculum adjustment suitable for their future professional career.

The multi-level education system of professional training in science-based chemical engineering has been tested and developed since 1997 up to the present in Lomonosov Moscow University of Fine Chemical Technology (MUTHT).

Motivated and adequate for particular person s capabilities choice of student for differently targeted educational programs is the main goal of the University at the first educational level. The course project "My future individual educational trajectory" has been tested during the second semester of the first year for three years by now. The project is targeted at increasing motivation for technical education, development of communication skills, capability to work as a team, encouraging student to think over the choice of specialty group for the Bachelor s Degree, choice of preferable curricula set for future University years and planning their professional career.

Still the student not always understand the perspectives of their future profession, are not enough motivated for scientific and engineering work, are often unable of critical self-evaluation which leads to underestimation of future difficulties in mastering the chosen education program.

p.strong: Involving student in curriculum development

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Curriculum Development
Author's preference: Oral

Radoslaw Czahajda2, Natalia Mazur3, Marija Stanojevic1, Giovanna Campogiani4 1Local BEST Group Belgrade, Belgrade, Serbia, 2Local BEST Group Wroclaw, Wroclaw, Poland, 3Local BEST Group Trondheim, Trondheim, Norway, 4Local BEST Group Rome, Rome, Italy

Through events and surveys, BEST (Board of European student of Technology) makes student aware of how they affect engineering education. BEST strives to have an impact not only on student but also on Higher Educational Institutions. We feel responsible for the development of our own curricula as we are the ones who are experiencing drawbacks firsthand.

In 2012-13 BEST conducted a survey among 2234 European engineering student. Out of those, only 55% ever had the possibility to evaluate their educational programme. 87% of them evaluated university courses and just 8% evaluated European Educational System. Only 5-10% of the evaluation is done through discussions while the rest is done online or through paper-forms. Even though student are asked for their opinion, 66% of all believe that university does not value it.

BEST events, such as Events on Education (EoEs) and Local Events on Educations (LEoEs) are an opportunity to exchange opinions amongst participants. Both formats aim to confront student, professors and company representatives on educational topics, through discussion groups, workshops and other interactive activities. While EoEs involve international student and focus on European issues, LEoEs aim at student of a single university and focus on the local educational environment. Evaluation of aforementioned events shows that gained outcomes are valuable for all stakeholders. Following paper will present and compare methods used to collect student input as well as differences among outcomes and their dissemination. Moreover benefits of organising such events will be discussed as we'd like them to become a common practice.

p.strong: Towards a continuous assessment of mathematical competences in a First Year of Aerospace Engineering

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Maths in EE
Author's preference: Either
Francisco Minguez, J.A. Mora??M.D. RosellLuis M. S?hez Ruiz Universitat Polit?ica de Val?ia, Valencia, Spain

Assessing mathematical competences is always a difficult issue, particularly in the first year of university engineering degrees when student with different backgrounds are learning together. The grade that student receive matters to all of them and should reflect as accurately as possible their degree of achievement. student should be aware that acquisition of mathematical competences is a continuous process and that any failure or problem they might face will be a sign of two facts: firstly and quite likely that they did not achieve in the past the expected competences and, secondly, that they are in a handicapped position to continue. Reversely, any successful achievement of expected competences in due time will place them in an advanced position toward achieving upper levels of knowledge in Mathematics and other subjects. On the other hand grading is a discreet process that comes from pictures taken through their "moments of evaluation" carried out by means of activities, lab classes, exams,... and should reflect the effort developed by the student in due time as well as the competences shown at each moment of the topic under study and, not to be dismissed, the competences whose specific "moments of evaluations" have already been done in the past. We expose how these ideas may be taken into account in order to carry out the process of grading mathematics competences achievement in the first year of the Aerospace Engineering degree at the School of Design Engineering in Valencia.

p.strong: Study Ability Through Engagement

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: student as partners
Author's preference: Oral
Sanna Unkuri, Laura Heinonen, Eeva Myller Aalto University Student Union, Espoo, Finland

Study ability is a student's working ability. It influences learning result, study success and well-being of the student and the study community. The Kyky project is coordinated by the National Union of University student in Finland (SYL). Other project partners include the Aalto University and the University of Tampere and their corresponding student unions.

The objective of the project is to establish the promotion of study ability as permanent part of university communities' activities and advance student integration, student participation and the work of student associations.

The material provides academic communities with information and incentives in order to increase study ability and study engagement. Study engagement is promoted through four themes: 1) Engagement and inspiration, 2) Trying and daring, 3) Competent and coping, and 4) Being well and taking care. The material is intended to be used at communities such as faculties, subject associations, student associations and organisations as well as various development groups.

p.strong: Entrepreneurship and Lean Manufacturing for Software Engineering.

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: The Global Engineer
Author's preference: Oral
Carlos Rioja del R, Arturo Morgado Est?z, Juan Jos?om?uez Jim?z University of C?z, Andalusia, Spain

One of the goals of Engineering Education is the education of our student and job performance in the labor market. For that, we introduce several related aspects focused on Software Engineering. As usual, when we talk about "Software", we talk about an intangible product, so we?l try to give an approach of concepts like Canvas Model, or Value Stream Mapping, but for Software Engineers.
Several success cases and entrepreneurship examples (using these tools) will be introduced too. Most of them, from the University of C?z (South Spain).

p.strong: The influence of the Crisis on the future of the European Higher Education Area

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Sustainability in EE
Author's preference: Oral
Urbano Dom?uez1, Jes??agdaleno2 1University of Valladolid, Valladolid, Spain, 2University of Valladolid, Valladolid, Spain
For years cuts in public funding have been implemented in many European university. Moreover, additional cuts are applied, trying to cope with the economic crisis and to reduce public deficits.

Those cuts are affecting some basic pillars of the European Union, which is not only a political and economic structure but also a social construction. With reference to the EHEA, the social dimension means equal opportunities for people in having an education of quality, and it is focussed in facilitating access and outcomes independently of the socio- economic background of student, and other factors which may lead to educational disadvantage. The Bologna process also considered social objectives in the building of the EHEA.

In some countries severe reductions in grants and study loans have been introduced at a time when registration fees have suffered a substantial increase. Also, the number of teachers has been reduced, they have more lecture hours and their salaries are falling. The authors discuss the effects of these cuts and analyze how a double segregation in EHE is being enhanced: nationally, for student from more deprived groups, and across the EHEA, for countries with bigger financial problems with respect to those who are better off. Some corrective measures are also discussed with a special focus on Engineering Education.

p.strong: Entrepreneurship Road Show - Promoting Entrepreneurship at Engineering Universitie

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Entrepreneurship of Employability
Author's preference: Oral
Pirre Hyotynen, Martti Kivioja Academic Engineers and Architects in Finland TEK, Helsinki, Finland

Academic Engineers and Architects in Finland - TEK actively works towards enhancing entrepreneurship and entrepreneurial skills of engineering student as well as working professionals. One of the recent actions includes a road show in university of engineering education that was organized in six university during 2013. This paper presents the targets, concept and result of the tour. In 2012 TEK conducted a master thesis study aiming to evaluate the current state of entrepreneurship education in Finnish university of technology and offer tools to develop it. One of the main targets of the road show was to distribute the result of this study. Alongside this, the target of the events was to promote entrepreneurship in general. The work shop style events brought together teachers, student, professionals and other stakeholders interested in entrepreneurship to share knowledge, ideas and best practices.

The road show events were organized in close cooperation with the university and student entrepreneurship societies, local entrepreneurship stakeholders and individual entrepreneurs. To have real life entrepreneurs as speakers was considered vital for the marketing and the content of the events. The main concept was similar in all road show events. The events included presentations, working group sessions, common discussion and networking dinner. The input was reported in a form of best practices or most crucial challenges. The participants appreciated especially the following: a chance to network with people interested in entrepreneurship, peer support and encouragement for entrepreneurial career, and best practices on how university can develop entrepreneurial skills of student.

p.strong: What makes a counterexample exemplary?

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Maths in EE
Author's preference: Oral

p.em: Ming Chi University of Technology, New Taipei City, Taiwan

body.p: This paper explored how first-year engineering student generated examples for statements believed to be true and counterexamples for statements believed to be false. This study based on the perspective that "examples as a research tool that provides a window' into a learner's mind". The participants comprised 112 first-year engineering student at a university of technology in Taiwan who previously completed courses of derivative and definite integrals. The questionnaire contained three false mathematical statements, and was designed to assess student ability to generate counterexamples regarding differentiation and integration. The primary data sources were the written responses to the questionnaire and interviews. Semi-structured interviews were carried out with 15 engineering student.

In this study, the engineering student could not generate proper counterexamples to refute the false mathematical statements. They often fail to check that the conditions are satisfied. this is because they are not fluent in using appropriate terms, notations, properties, or do not recognize the role of such conditions. To improve the understanding of engineering student regarding calculus concepts, teachers must understand student' misconceptions and spend additional time interpreting relevant concepts. Counterexamples can be used for assessment of learners' understanding in a broad sense. Furthermore, uses of counterexamples for teaching, in selecting instructional examples it is important to take into account learners' preconceptions and misconceptions. In our opinion, the power of these examples is also testified by the fact that they tend to impress in the memory of student, because of their peculiar features, thus further helping their learning process.

p.strong: The Changing Role of university in the 21st Century - Teachers and Learners Needs

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Curriculum Development
Author's preference: Either

p.em: Budapest University of Technology and Economics, Budapest, Hungary

body.p: The aim of this presentation is to provide an insight into the role of higher education in the information-driven world regarding how to best satisfy the needs of teachers and learners. Between 2009-2011 the Budapest University of Technology and Economics implemented the SROP project Training of trainers at the Budapest University of Technology and Economics" The general aim of the project was contributing to the reduction of those missing trainer competences that are necessary for the implementation of the requirements of the Bologna-process, the European Qualifications Framework and the LLL strategy. The trainings realized within the frameworks of the project were based on a previous needs assessment of the institute.
