The internal survey served the purpose of having a comprehensive picture on the relevant training needs within the teaching staff. Another survey regarding the training needs of teaching and administrative staff in Hungarian higher education is connected with the MELLearN Network (Hungarian University Lifelong Learning Network). One of the main aims of Network is to have a comprehensive picture on the training needs of trainers and staff working in higher education, and initiating trainings that provide the necessary skills, knowledge required by them. In the autum2012 members of the association decided to establish a training database to satisfy arising training needs of teachers and workers of partner institutions. This common training database, being the first phase of the survey, ensures the optimal use of institutional resources and wider range of available training opportunities. In the 2. phase (spring, 2013) we investigated the training needs of instructors and workers via online survey. This survey based on the experiences of the previous research at Budapest University of Technology and Economics. Our research aimed to reveal the use of different teaching methods, ways of organizing education among participant and their training needs. 734 instructors and administrative staff filled in the online questionnaire from 18 higher educational institutions. Having a collaborative partnership with the University of Oulu, the survey was also conducted in Finland in autumn 2013, using the same pattern, and a comparative analysis was done to evaluate the differences and similarities of Hungarian and Finnish training needs. On the basis of the result MELLearN Association aims to develop its training database in accordance with revealed training needs. Almost every university is continuously working on to find out, how to improve the efficiency of the educational process. But first we have to investigate the learning attitude, the formal and non-formal learning habits of the student and understand the main characteristics of the educational processes within the institution. Therefore, after the first two surveys on teachers' and administrative staff's training needs, the Budapest University of Technology and Economics conducted an online survey among its student to learn more about their learning habits. Almost one third of the 20,000 student answered the quiestionnaire, which contained two parts, a detailed survey about the general learning circumstances and an other one about Kolb's learning style inventory (Kolb test). Utilizing the educational achievement of these student we may point out some relations among the success in the university" and learning styles, learning strategies, environmental impacts, certain attitudes and personal characteristics. The final goal of the project is to manifest some strategic steps in order to improve the educational processes of the university, as in some cases it can be useful for supporting decisions in the near future. On the other hand it can help to accomplish better student consultancy.

p.strong: Developing Engineering Expertise within Numerical Methods

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Maths in EE
Author's preference: Oral
Desmond Adair2, Martin Jaeger1 1University of Tasmania, Australia, Australia, 2Nazarbayev University, Republic of Kazakhstan, Kazakhstan

The goal of this paper is to incorporate key findings from earlier works found in the literature, concerning the development of engineering expertise for undergraduate student; specifically here, the development of expertise within numerical methods commonly found in today's professional engineering, and, to test if the use of these findings, substantially improve student expertise. The research is based on the development of an existing course on Numerical Methods for Engineering, and the research aims are to allow student to construct deeper conceptual knowledge, to develop substantial skills to apply this conceptual knowledge, to practice their newly acquired skills and knowledge using authentic engineering projects, and finally to test if the new approach does indeed produce better engineering expertise.

It is not the intention here to spontaneously create experts from undergraduate student as expertise takes significant time to develop. People who have considerable expertise, approach problems by considering the whole problem prior to attempting specific methods and they classify problems based on deep features, such as general principles that govern the correct solution rather than shallow features, such as the relationship between objects in mechanics.

p.strong: Thinking like an engineer: using engineering habits of mind to redesign engineering education for global competitiveness

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: The Attractiveness of Engineering
Author's preference: Oral
Bill Lucas, Janet Hanson Centre for Real World Learning, University of Winchester, Winchester, UK

If we want to ensure that young engineers are ready to meet the challenges of the future and can operate in a global environment, we need to know how successful engineers think and act when faced with challenging problems. Once we have identified these distinctive engineering habits of mind' (EHoM) we can then suggest how the education and training system might be re-designed to ensure the cultivation of these EHoM in school, college and university. Funded by the Royal Academy of Engineering, our research found that there was considerable agreement about the six habits of mind that engineers use most frequently when engaged in the core activities of making' things or making things work better'. We suggest that active teaching approach, such as PBL or CDIO, can in themselves only take the learner so far, but if the curriculum overtly articulates EHoM as an outcome of learning and provides student with opportunities to develop and practice them at all levels of the education system, more successful learning will occur. In addition to developing our earlier work at the Centre for Real World Learning in which we developed a model of practical learning, we also drew on the habits of mind approach which can be found in the engineering education community in the USA and on habits of mind developed in science and mathematics education. This presentation will outline the key findings from our interviews with engineers and engineers educators and discuss the six EHoM that were agreed through this process.

p.strong: Flipped learning: comparing the student experience from 1st year to postgraduate

body.p: Status: Accepted
Category: Curriculum Development
Author's preference: Oral
Keith Willey, Anne Gardner, A Kadi University of Technology Sydney, Sydney, NSW, Australia

While flipped instruction may be standard practice in many social science programs it is often promoted as a recent innovation in learning design within science and technology classrooms. Flipped instruction is a form of blended learning that replaces transmission-based lectures with more participative, interactive and collaborative learning opportunities. Activities are typically undertaken before, during and after class, freeing in class time to participate in activities often engaging with concepts at a higher level. Flipped activities typically require student to undertake out of class preparation, engage in in-class collaboration and dialogue and adopt a more independent approach to their learning.

Typically instructors focus on their student' cognitive development in relation to the subject material. However, student' expectations of how a subject is delivered and their level of meta cognitive skill development will also affect how they engage with the subject content and hence impact their learning. Our investigation is concerned with how these factors impact student' response to flipped instruction.

This paper reports the exploratory phase of a study investigating the impact of flipped instruction on first year, third year and postgraduate student. We found that most student preferred flipped instruction compared to the more traditional lecture style approach agreeing that it had a positive impact on their learning experience. There was also evidence that the different learning expectations and focus of the undergraduate student in particular those in first-year meant that many may not be ready for the responsibility and independence demanded to engage with flipped instruction without scaffolding and support.
